urn:contentItem:5VSN-9861-F0J6-J4C5-00000-00'Pendulum has swung' against tech giants;Internet Regulation2019-04-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9'Pendulum has swung' against tech giantsInternet RegulationJennifer Duke

A senior Google executive has thrown his support behind globally consistent privacy legislation as he acknowledged public opinion had soured after videos of the Christchurch terrorist attack overwhelmed the digital behemoths.

The search giant's senior vice-president for global affairs, Kent Walker, said yesterday he supported the "general notion" of more privacy regulation globally and described Europe's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) as a "workable model" even if "different countries will want to make adjustments".

"We would support the general notion of more privacy legislation, ideally that is harmonised with privacy rules that we are seeing in other countries around the world," Mr Walker said. "I think that makes it not only easier to comply with but contributes to having a shared expectation of how you can have control over your privacy, transparency, inter-operability [moving information from one service to another] - that works best if it's a shared framework." His comments follow Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg making a similar call for globally consistent data rules, potentially similar to GDPR. Facebook, Google and the other digital giants are under substantial pressure after the New Zealand massacre was livestreamed on Facebook and then re-uploaded millions of times. Since then, the Australian government has proposed new legislation, including prison time for executives and billions of dollars in fines, should platforms not rapidly remove "abhorrent violent material".

Mr Walker declined to comment on the legislation, saying he was yet to see it, but acknowledged the reaction globally to the events in Christchurch had been significant.

"I think there's no question that the pendulum has swung from the relatively uncritical support of technology to significant concerns about unintended side effects and abuses of technological platforms," he said.

In response to the events in New Zealand, he said the search giant was rethinking some of its technology to stop terrorists online. "We're working on the question of limits on livestreaming [and] other things we can do to be able to quickly respond to these kinds of attacks on our systems," Mr Walker said.

He admitted that videos of terrorist attacks were "not a new development" but said the difference this time was how many people were re-uploading the footage in a co-ordinated way.

"That's what created the challenges in removing so much. We saw tens of thousands of uploads, Facebook saw many more than that, which effectively overwhelmed the system, which had effectively been satisfactory up until that point," he said. "We're now trying to build systems that allow us to respond quickly in the event of these kinds of attacks or state-sponsored attacks or other sorts of things on the platform." Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims on Sunday welcomed Mr Zuckerberg's "recognition" that big tech companies such as Facebook and Google "have to be accountable for what people see [on their platforms]". But he said countries might have to move on their own initially as the issue was pressing and worldwide regulatory alignment was unlikely in the short term.

On Monday morning, executives in Espoo, Finland, where industrial group Kone is based, were feeling confident. 

By the afternoon, its leadership was straining to explain why a potential deal for a rival’s business had become too risky and fallen through. Shares in the Finnish company had dropped as much as 5.6 per cent. 

Germany’s Thyssenkrupp, which is selling its profitable elevators division, released a statement saying it had chosen to “prioritise” talks with two private equity groups —— one led by Blackstone and Carlyle, the other by Advent and Cinven. 

That left Kone, which bid in partnership with private equity group CVC about €1bn more than its rivals, out in the cold —— though Kone’s chief executive Henrik Ehrnrooth (below) told DD’s Kaye Wiggins that it had decided to pull out hours earlier, when Moody’s downgraded Thyssenkrupp’s debt. 

You can read his explanation and the FT story on the developments  here. 

Whatever happened, Kone’s loss is a boon for the buyout groups in what could well become the continent’s biggest-ever private equity deal. 

The removal of the deepest-pocketed bidder raises a question for buyout groups that are used to aggressive bidding wars: if money doesn’t necessarily talk in Germany, how do you win? 

Both private equity consortiums will fight to get the  influential trade unions on side. Beyond that, is it local connections —— such as the Advent group’s links to a well-connected Ruhr Valley non-profit, the RAG Foundation —— that count? Or a record of megadeals and a giant real estate business, à la Blackstone? 

The outcome might offer buyout groups some lessons in what works in Germany, a market they’re increasingly moving into. Or, it may not. Thyssenkrupp has consistently said it could list the business rather than sell it off, a point it reiterated today.

That would likely leave many of Europe’s top bankers and dealmakers, who’ve spent countless hours on the process, tearing their hair out. 

If you want to go deeper on why PE is so hungry for this asset, read Kaye’s explainer  here. And if you want to understand the crisis at Thyssenkrupp better, flashback  to our coverage  from last year.

Uefa’s Man City ban has rocked more than just European football

The news late on Friday that Abu Dhabi-owned Manchester City has been banned from playing in the Champions League for the next two seasons didn’t just rock European football. 

It’s being felt everywhere from the offices of top London lawyers to investors in China, the Middle East and the US. 

This is a club, after all, whose parent company  received a $500m investment late last year from none other than US private equity powerhouse Silver Lake.

Now, the sanity of Silver Lake’s investment —— which already seemed frothy at a $4.8bn valuation —— is looking more questionable. 

If you need to catch up, read the news on the Man City ban by Uefa, European football’s governing body,  here. 

Manchester City’s leadership plans to appeal the extraordinary sanction to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, considered the final arbiter of global sports disputes. 

To mount its legal comeback, the club has enlisted London-based Monckton Chambers and Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer, as well as Swiss attorneys Kellerhals Carrard. It will not go down without a fight, conclude the FT’s Murad Ahmed and Arash Massoudi in  their analysis of the situation. 

Depending on what defence this legal team opts for, they could even bring down Europe’s “financial fair play” regulatory regime, designed to prevent clubs from spending beyond their means, in the process.

The club is considering an explosive legal strategy in which it will argue that not only did it not breach the regulations, but that the rules should not exist at all. If successful, such a strategy could tilt the balance of power in the sport to those with deep pockets. 

They include a consortium-led by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, which  is in talks to acquire England’s Newcastle United, and Alisher Usmanov, an Uzbek-born Russian billionaire, who  has been finding ways to inject capital into Everton. 

Both have the wealth to transform the teams by spending hundreds of millions of pounds on the world’s best players. They would be constrained if the financial fair play regime remains in place, however.

If you want to go deeper, join Murad and Arash in person on March 5 in London  at the FT’s Business of Football Summit.

Eric Salama has been ousted as chief executive of Kantar, the market data business he helped build, after private equity group Bain Capital decided to cut short his remaining time at the company. More  here.

Anglo American Platinum’s chief executive Chris Griffith, the company veteran regarded as a potential candidate for the top job at parent group Anglo American, is to step down after more than seven years at the helm. More  here.

Penguin Books USA issued the following book description:

Tools and Weapons: The Promise and the Peril of the Digital Age, by Brad Smith and Carol Ann Browne, and foreword by Bill Gates

Microsoft President Brad Smith operates by a simple core belief: When your technology changes the world, you bear a responsibility to help address the world you have helped create. This might seem uncontroversial, but it flies in the face of a tech sector long obsessed with rapid growth and sometimes on disruption as an end in itself.

While sweeping digital transformation holds great promise, we have reached an inflection point. The world has turned information technology into both a powerful tool and a formidable weapon, and new approaches are needed to manage an era defined by even more powerful inventions like artificial intelligence. Companies that create technology must accept greater responsibility for the future, and governments will need to regulate technology by moving faster and catching up with the pace of innovation.

In Tools and Weapons, Brad Smith and Carol Ann Browne bring us a captivating narrative from the cockpit of one of the world's largest and most powerful tech companies as it finds itself in the middle of some of the thorniest emerging issues of our time.

These are challenges that come with no preexisting playbook, including privacy, cybercrime and cyberwar, social media, the moral conundrums of artificial intelligence, big tech's relationship to inequality, and the challenges for democracy, far and near.

While in no way a self-glorifying "Microsoft memoir," the book pulls back the curtain remarkably wide onto some of the company's most crucial recent decision points as it strives to protect the hopes technology offers against the very real threats it also presents. There are huge ramifications for communities and countries, and Brad Smith provides a thoughtful and urgent contribution to that effort.

urn:contentItem:5Y8C-VM81-DYG2-R4DY-00000-00Penguin Random House Publishes 'The Ones We've Been Waiting For' by Charlotte Alter2020-02-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisPenguin Random House Publishes 'The Ones We've Been Waiting For' by Charlotte AlterTargeted News ServiceNEW YORK

Penguin Random House published the following book - "The Ones We've Been Waiting For, How a New Generation of Leaders Will Transform America" by Charlotte Alter:

A new generation is stepping up. There are now twenty-six millennials in Congress-a fivefold increase gained in the 2018 midterms alone. They are governing Midwestern cities and college towns, running for city councils, and serving in state legislatures. They are acting urgently on climate change (because they are going to live it); they care deeply about student debt (because they have it); they are utilizing big tech but still want to regulate it (because they understand how it works). In The Ones We've Been Waiting For, TIME correspondent Charlotte Alter defines the class of young leaders who are remaking the nation-how grappling with 9/11 as teens, serving in Iraq and Afghanistan, occupying Wall Street and protesting with Black Lives Matter, and shouldering their way into a financially rigged political system has shaped the people who will govern the future.

Through the experiences of millennial leaders-from progressive firebrand Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez to Democratic presidential hopeful Pete Buttigieg to Republican up-and-comer Elise Stefanik-Charlotte Alter gives the big-picture look at how this generation governs differently than their elders, and how they may drag us out of our current political despair. Millennials have already revolutionized technology, commerce, and media and have powered the major social movements of our time. Now government is ripe for disruption. The Ones We've Been Waiting For is a hopeful glimpse into a bright new generation of political leaders, and what America might look like when they are in charge.

About the Author

Charlotte Alter is a national correspondent for TIME, covering the 2016, 2018, and 2020 campaigns, youth social movements, and women in politics. Her work has also appeared in The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal.

Hardcover | $27.00

Published by Viking

Sep 22, 2019( Activist Post: http://www.activistpost.com Delivered by Newstex) ;   https://www.activistpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/artificial-intelligence-OTN.jpgBy Daniel Taylor[1] A.I. driven social scores to supplant the Constitution? Professor Larry Backer of Penn State University writes in a 2018 paper that resistance to social credit systems in the West could be dissolved when the masses are 'socialized as a collective' and 'the great culture management machinery of Western society develop a narrative in which such activity is naturalized within Western culture.'

A 2018 paper written by prominent law professor Larry Backer of Penn State[2] discussed the ways in which a social credit system could be implemented in the West. Backer writes that the shift in law with this system will 'change the focus of public law from Constitution and rule of law to analytics and algorithm' In the paper, titled 'Next Generation Law: Data Driven Governance and Accountability Based Regulatory Systems in the West, and Social Credit Regimes in China[3]', Backer describes moves to social credit in the West as 'fractured', but gives guidance on how societal norms could be steadily pushed to accept this system. Backer proposes that the 'great culture management machinery' of the West normalize the idea of social credit and sharing private data. Backer writes: But is it possible to socialize the masses, or even mass democracy as a collective, to embrace this pattern of data disclosure beyond these immediately self-serving closed loop systems? Would it be possible for the state to develop systems for the enforcement of laws (criminal and regulatory) that depends on intelligence by inducing the masses to serve as positive contributors of data necessary for enforcement or regulation? The answer, in Western liberal democracies, may depend on the ability of the great culture management machinery of Western society- its television, movies and other related media-to develop a narrative in which such activity is naturalized within Western culture. As Big Tech and artificial intelligence creep further into our lives, a grid of high tech surveillance has entangled us. As if to pacify resistance, these systems (Google Home, Apple watches, Amazon Alexa) offer 'convenience' in the form of targeted ads, personalized content and other features. In reality, this system is meant to determine whether or not you will be allowed to function in modern society. The Trump admin is reportedly considering using this surveillance grid to monitor the population[4] for signs of mental illness, triggering authorities to confiscate firearms from 'dangerous individuals'. In 2013, Old-Thinker News asked the question 'Will Insurance Companies Use Smart Appliances to Monitor 'Unhealthy' Habits?[5]' As this 2013 Wall Street Journal[6] article stated, your insurance company: already knows whether you've been taking your meds, getting your teeth cleaned and going for regular medical checkups. Now some employers or their insurance companies are tracking what staffers eat, where they shop and how much weight they're putting on — and taking action to keep them in line. Artificial intelligence, programmed by power hungry individuals, is steadily taking over our society. It is already censoring political opinions. It will be making medical, education, and financial decisions. Humans are to be sidelined. The social credit system will be watching you closely for any deviant behavior. If you aren't careful, you will become an outcast. Access to food, transportation and medical care will be denied.Also Read from Activist Post: Want Cheaper Insurance Rates? You Can Have It If You Let Companies Track and Manage Your Life[7] This article was sourced from Old Thinker News[8]. Subscribe to Activist Post[9] for truth, peace, and freedom news. The volume contains write-ups of many of the programs[2] featured at the November 2019 Appellate Judges Education Institute Summit[3] in Washington, DC. urn:contentItem:5GG3-B861-JDJ6-K2F3-00000-00Pentagon's Silicon Valley push angers defense contractors2015-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisPentagon's Silicon Valley push angers defense contractorsLeigh Munsil,Philip Ewing

Defense Secretary Ash Carter may have started a war with some of the nation's biggest arms manufacturers.

Carter has made a direct pitch to Silicon Valley companies to offer new military technologies, believing the more agile tech companies could deliver a speed and agility edge over stodgy military establishment companies comfortable with their position inside the Beltway.

It's a battle that pits innovators like Google against traditional players like Raytheon and Northrop Grumman in the battle over technologies ranging from cybersecurity to data management and precision navigation. And now the defense contractors are going public with their displeasure.

The counteroffensive began with a blunt rebuke in May by the head of Northrop Grumman, Wes Bush, who said the types of commercial technologies that the Pentagon is eyeing, "being inherently broadly available, offers no national security advantages by definition."

Defense industry leaders aren't just offended by the implication that small hardware startups and tech giants such as Facebook and Google are outpacing them in ingenuity. More important, they argue, those companies don't have the slightest idea about military needs or understand how to navigate the Pentagon's acquisition system -- in short, to make their ideas reality.

Carter, a physicist with deep ties to academia who in 2013 advised a Silicon Valley computer data firm called Box, Inc., has established a Pentagon outpost in Mountain View, Calif., where Defense Department personnel will try to strengthen ties between the Defense Department and a roster of cutting-edge tech players.

He met with a series of them earlier this year on a West Coast trip and last week addressed a conference in Sun Valley, Idaho, that defense officials described as continuation of his outreach to the nontraditional players in private industry.

Also on POLITICO

Iran critics are illogical, Obama says

MICHAEL CROWLEY

But if Carter and the Pentagon really want to make progress, it's going to take a lot more work, say defense industry leaders, who warn it will be difficult for the Pentagon to buy hardware or software of the caliber it wants with the full support that it needs.

"Silicon Valley folks? Their main focus is on speed to market," said Michael Daly, chief technology officer for Raytheon Cybersecurity and Special Missions. "When you're making technology in the defense market, you also have to address other aspects, including mission assurance, acquisition compliance -- these things are important ... there's an overhead to that. That can slow you down if you're not structured to deal with it."

Products built for the military must comply not only with U.S. acquisitions law but international regulations for weapons, Daly said. Defense industry players get that. They also get that having the U.S. government as a customer can require long-term support that can be much more complicated than for commercial or even other government customers.

As an example, Daly cited a Patriot missile battery -- also built by Raytheon. The Army might own one for 30 years, he said, meaning it could need 30 years' worth of support to protect it from potential new cyber-vulnerabilities.

The Pentagon press office declined to respond to questions. But a defense official close to Carter argued that industry advocacy groups have publicly reacted favorably to the Silicon Valley proposals and that added competition should be welcomed by the establishment defense industry.

"We want to see competition, and we want to be able to tap into the best ideas of industry," said the official, who asked not to be identified because he was not authorized to speak publicly. "The nation's success is built on competition, and we want to see more of it."

The Pentagon is about to make an award on the new Long Range Strike Bomber to either Northrop Grumman or a Lockheed-Boeing team, the official added, and large contracts for upgrades to platforms are in the pipeline.

"No one's saying that the big, industrial-base guys are not innovating," the official said. "But, at the same time, there is no doubt a wealth of innovation in what is known at the cradle of innovation -- Silicon Valley -- that will ultimately have application to" the Department of Defense.

Also on POLITICO

Iran deal: Big oil's mixed bag

SARA STEFANINI

No one expects the Pentagon to ask Google to build a new surface-to-air missile, but defense industry leaders chafe at the basic idea they can't deliver software or hardware as well as anyone, especially given the special requirements involved with a customer that can be as difficult as the military.

The much-hyped Silicon Valley push "has rubbed a lot of people in the industry the wrong way," said one official with a major defense-focused services firm, "when they decide to go [outside] the Beltway and quote-unquote 'foster new ideas.'"

Carter's implication is the Pentagon's current slate of contractors can't come up with new ideas -- which is "kind of a slap in the face to some of the cool things going on in industry," the official said.

Silicon Valley's startups and established tech companies aren't under the same regulatory constraints that defense industry leaders call a thorn in their sides -- piles of paperwork, audits and restraints on buying commercial, off-the-shelf parts for use on defense contracts. Tech companies won't be receptive to working with the Pentagon unless they're somehow exempted from restrictive regulations, some in the defense industry argue.

The Pentagon "would go to Google, and Google would go: 'You want my margins to be what? You want my profit to be what?'" the official said.

Carter, however, argues that the government and Big Tech can make it work by doing things in a new way. On a visit to Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., this spring to announce the outreach, Carter even joked about the Pentagon's legacy programs and vendors.

"What's in it for Silicon Valley?" the moderator asked him after his speech. "Why enter DoD's acquisition system?"

"Well, I hope you don't have to enter DoD's acquisition system," Carter quipped, drawing laughter from the audience. One idea behind his outreach to the West Coast, he said, was to make it easier to work with companies on high-tech products, including cyber services and a major effort to create a new system for precision navigation and timing to help offset potential threats to the Global Positioning System.

The U.S. can't afford to continue buying high technology with old-style Pentagon programs, defense officials argue.

"In order to sustain technological superiority, the department must take advantage of the rapid evolution of emerging commercial technologies that, when integrated with military systems and novel concepts of operation, will be a source of battlefield advantage," wrote Deputy Defense Secretary Robert Work in a memo this month specifying the Mountain View operation.

The new unit "will serve as the hub for the department's core initiative to increase DoD's communication with, knowledge of, and access to innovating leading edge technologies from high tech, startup companies and entrepreneurs," Work wrote.

In response, some incumbent defense firms said they've already begun their own Silicon Valley outreach efforts. Raytheon has one, Daly said, and the French defense, aerospace and airline security company Thales is seizing on Carter's push with its own innovation initiative, said Pete Roney, vice president for innovation and technology at ThalesUSA.

But parochialism in the U.S. defense industry is real, he added.

"The primes [are] looking over at the Valley and saying, 'OK guys, just stay in your little box over there and go do Facebook stuff -- we'll work on defense,'" Roney said. "I think there is quite a bit of that sentiment."

San Jose, California is undergoing an urban development revolution calculated to keep it as the thriving heart of a region renowned for technological innovation. | AP Photo

Former Rep. Jim Moran (D-Va.), who now represents several defense firms at the Washington law-lobby shop of McDermott Will & Emery, argued that there's a cultural difference between defense firms and Silicon Valley. National security is a priority for the defense-industrial complex, whereas profit is a greater goal for technology companies.

"The big defense firms that we work with, they don't commercialize the products that they make for the Pentagon," Moran said. "They are very conscientious of maintaining security, of not letting people usurp the technological prowess that the Defense Department has been able to bring about. And it is kind of a different mindset -- Silicon Valley wants to go public immediately. That's their objective."

The difference in size between the defense market and the global market is one key reason why the historic ties frayed between the Pentagon and some of California's high-tech players. In the past, the U.S. government was the only developer and buyer of electronics or other such equipment. Today, with billions of cellphone and computer users around the world, the U.S. government by itself holds much less sway.

Despite consternation from the defense industry and skepticism by some tech watchers, there are successful precedents for outreach by the defense and intelligence worlds into the Silicon Valley orbit, said Randy Sabett, vice chairman of the privacy and data protection practice group at Cooley, a major law firm with many tech clients.

For example, in 2011 then-Deputy Defense Secretary William Lynn unveiled his idea for a "cyber accelerator" program at the RSA conference in San Francisco. That effort yielded progress, Sabett said, as could Carter's.

"These kinds of things take time," Sabett said. "They're looking at broad changes, it seems ... there's more emphasis on changes than has been there in the past."

urn:contentItem:5X05-FB41-JCF0-82D3-00000-00Pentagon to hire ethicist to help guide artificial intelligence2019-09-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisPentagon to hire ethicist to help guide artificial intelligence

Good morning. This is your CQ Cyber newsletter for Tuesday, Sept. 3, 2019.

Editor's Note: CQ Cyber is changing delivery dates to better serve our readers. Starting Sept. 10, the newsletter will publish Tuesdays and Fridays instead of Mondays and Thursdays. Our goal is to provide timely news, deep analysis, and a forward look on cyber and technology news.

TOPLINES

1. AI ethicist: The Pentagon is seeking an ethicist to join its Joint Artificial Intelligence Center, which is overseeing the military's development of artificial intelligence, in part to address fears that such technologies could lead to fully automated weapons without human supervision.

2. Ransoming elections: The country's top cybersecurity agency is worried that local election systems could suffer from ransomware attacks and is asking states to take precautions, but the voluntary program could fall short of ensuring adequate security.

3. The Cloud as a utility: A group of House Democrats is pressing Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin to designate cloud services offered by top U.S. tech giants as utilities to protect the U.S. financial system from data breaches.

4. Driverless directives: Key U.S. agencies are edging closer to drawing up mandatory rules governing the development and use of driverless cars, potentially moving away from a voluntary system that companies follow now.

FULL BRIEFING

1. Pentagon seeks an ethicist for its artificial intelligence center

The Pentagon is seeking an ethicist for the office that's overseeing the military's artificial intelligence technologies to consider the ethical implications of automated weapons systems, Air Force Lt. Gen. John N.T. "Jack" Shanahan, director of the Defense Department's Joint Artificial Intelligence Center, told reporters at a news briefing Friday.

"In 35-plus years in uniform, I've never spent the amount of time I'm spending now thinking about the ethical employment of artificial intelligence," Shanahan told reporters. "We take it very seriously."

The center will select "someone who's an ethicist and not just a technical person" to begin considering moral questions on what is and is not acceptable in the use of such technologies, he said.

The Pentagon also favors international discussion on norms and future rules of engagement on deploying weapons systems enabled by artificial intelligence, Shanahan said. The Pentagon is in discussions with the State Department on how to engage with allies and partners around the world on developing norms governing the use of artificial intelligence in military applications, Shanahan said.

Read more from my story here.

2. Cyber agency wants to help states combat ransomware targeting elections

The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency last week said it was worried that voter registration databases and other systems tied to elections could suffer from crippling ransomware ahead of the 2020 elections.

The agency's concern stems from dozens of ransomware attacks in the past year that already have shutdown city and county governments across the country, forcing many of them to suspend normal services until their computers can be restored.

"Recent history has shown that state and county governments and those who support them are targets for ransomware attacks," Christopher Krebs, the agency director, said in a statement. "Voter registration databases could be an attractive target for these attacks. A successful ransomware attack at a critical point before an election could limit access to information and has the potential to undermine public confidence in the election itself."

The agency is working with state officials and private companies to protect election databases and ensure they have a plan to respond to ransomware attacks, Krebs said.

The agency, part of the Homeland Security Department, has a checklist of things to do to prevent a ransomware attack and to recover from one. They include backing up data in devices that are not connected to the internet, updating and patching software in a timely manner, reviewing security procedures and plans to recover if attacked, and doing drills based on other ransomware attacks.

But the effort is entirely voluntary, and it's up to states to choose to work with CISA or not.

Leaving it up to the states to choose means the potential dangers of a ransomware attack on elections could remain unaddressed, Jake Williams, a former National Security Agency hacker and founder of cybersecurity firm Rendition InfoSec, wrote on Twitter.

"The federal government won't be able to fix this and that's part of the problem," Williams wrote. "I want to respect state's rights, but this might be the time to create mandatory federal standards around voting safety."

3. Democrats ask Mnuchin to oversee Big Tech cloud products

Two Democrats on the House Financial Services Committee are pressing Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin to designate cloud services offered by three tech giants -- Google, Microsoft and Amazon -- as important utilities crucial to financial markets to protect the United States from data breaches.

The Democrats, Reps. Nydia M. Velazquez of New York and Katie Porter of California, asked Mnuchin in an Aug. 22 letter to convene a meeting of the department's Financial Stability Oversight Council to consider deeming Google Cloud, Microsoft Azure and Amazon Web Services as "systemically important financial market utilities," known as SIFMUs.

Velazquez and Porter said their letter was precipitated by the recent breach of Capital One Bank, which uses Amazon Web Services. The breach is estimated to have affected 100 million individuals in the United States. In 2018, Amazon Web Services was estimated to power roughly 40 percent of the internet, according to the Verge, including services such as Netflix and Slack.

"While it has been determined that an error by Capital One enabled the breach, the incident raises new and serious questions about banks' and financial institutions' dependence on cloud services for their data needs -- and the risks these systems pose to the safety and stability of the financial system," the Democrats wrote.

Designating various cloud services as SIFMUs would "subject the tech firms to enhanced oversight by the Federal Reserve to ensure a cloud failure of a leading financial institution would not create a catastrophic risk to the nation's financial system," the Democrats said.

The letter from Velazquez and Porter is available here.

-- Dean DeChiaro

4. Driverless car makers may face mandatory rules

The federal government has so far relied primarily on voluntary guidance to oversee the development of driverless cars and trucks, but that could change soon.

Last week was the deadline for sending public comments to the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration about how they should regulate the industry.

Cars and truck have been developing varying levels of autonomy over the years, starting decades back with cruise control and today using an array of crash avoidance systems.

Read more from Jessica Wehrman's story here.

SCHEDULES

Check out CQ's daily schedule of congressional hearings and more. If you miss a hearing, look for our transcripts coverage here. And if you want more information about our cyber coverage, or to subscribe to this newsletter, go here.

Follow us on Twitter @CQNow for the latest cybersecurity and advanced technology developments on and off the Hill. And, as always, send any tips, questions or feedback to Gopal Ratnam, CQ Roll Call senior staff writer, at gopalratnam@cqrollcall.com or Dean DeChiaro, CQ Roll Call technology reporter, at deandechiaro@cqrollcall.com

urn:contentItem:5T4T-B321-DY0P-G3M1-00000-00Pentagon turns to rapid prototyping, hoping for big tech gains, but accepting new risks2018-08-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisPentagon turns to rapid prototyping, hoping for big tech gains, but accepting new risks

Pentagon acquisition executives have begun using a new rapid prototyping and fielding authority that could streamline traditional weapon system development, but might also test the patience of Congress should it lead to costly failures.

The new authority, which has generated significant buzz within the Defense Department's acquisition community, comes from section 804 of the Fiscal Year 2016 National Defense Authorization Act.

Section 804 provides DOD a pathway to accelerate rapid prototyping for "middle tier capabilities" that can be fielded within five years or use proven technologies to upgrade existing systems. Perhaps most importantly, programs operating under 804 authority are allowed to bypass the Joint Requirements Oversight Council and the Joint Capabilities Integration Development System, oversight bodies that critics say slow the acquisition process.

Air Force acquisition chief Will Roper, the former director of the Strategic Capabilities Office, has positioned his service as the leading user of the new authority, earlier this month employing 804 to launch development of the Air-Launched Rapid Response weapon and the Next-Generation Overhead Persistent Infrared satellite constellation.

In a promotional video for Defense Acquisition University, Roper said Air Force program managers are well aware of his affinity for section 804.

"They have quickly realized that I love 804, and I do not like traditional acquisition plans that I'm not going to see complete within the next decade," he said. "They have quickly realized don't bring in traditional acquisition and they have all realigned program plans around 804."

In July, Inside Defense obtained a list of programs the Air Force and the other services told Congress they are considering for 804 authority.

Along with the two programs begun earlier this month, the Air Force is contemplating using 804 for the B-52 Commercial Engine Replacement Program, the new light-attack aircraft, F-22 modernization and protected tactical enterprise services.

Roper said in the DAU video that if there is a developmental program that "doesn't naturally lend itself to this authority, I haven't found it yet."

Bruce Jette, the Army's acquisition chief, also appeared in the DAU video and said his service wants "product, not process" and is "looking very hard" at using section 804 for the Future Vertical Lift program as well as some systems for directed energy, air defense and small missiles.

"Part of this is culture," he said. "Don't get perfect. Where's the good break point? Let's see what we can do in five years."

Critics warn of risks

But Frank Kendall, the former under secretary of defense for acquisition, technology and logistics, said the new rapid prototyping authorities won't eliminate the complexities of technology development.

"What determines how long a development program takes is the product," he told Inside Defense. "Complexity and technical difficulty drive schedule. That can't be wished away. Requirements set by operators drive both complexity and technical difficulty. You have to begin there."

Kendall said it is possible to build some kinds of prototypes quickly if requirements are reduced and designs are simplified.

"Whether an operator will want that product is another question," he said. "It's also possible to set totally unrealistic schedules and get industry to bid on them. There is a great deal of history that teaches us that this is a really bad idea."

Andrew Hunter, an analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies who previously ran the Pentagon's Joint Rapid Acquisition Cell, said he understands the appeal of section 804.

"Section 804 authority clearly provides an alternative path in the acquisition system that exempts programs from many of the existing rules," he said. "For this reason, it is appealing to those looking to streamline acquisition oversight and accelerate the initiation of development programs."

Like Kendall, however, Hunter said 804 authority is unlikely to alter the difficulty of technology development or the inherent need for trade-offs.

"Putting the priority on delivering capability faster means compromising to some extent on one or more other traditional acquisition priorities such as unit cost, performance or sustainability," he said.

Hunter added that there aren't clear program oversight rules for section 804.

"That is similar to the situation with [other transaction authority] where anything is possible, but the very lack of established rules means only a small cadre of experts currently feel comfortable using them," he said. "I think, over time, the flexibility of section 804 authority will likely prove its particular value for certain kinds of development efforts, and a body of newer oversight mechanisms will develop optimized for those efforts."

Wooing Congress

Because 804 is such a new tool, it has yet to be tested with one of the most powerful audiences -- Congress.

Though lawmakers voted to include 804 in the FY-16 NDAA and have frequently pushed for faster defense acquisition, the Pentagon has yet to use 804 it in a meaningful way that leads to what most technology developers say is inevitable and, in many cases, desirable: failure.

"Let's see what happens when they go before Congress with a $500 million failure and say, 'Boy, we sure learned a lot,'" said one former senior DOD official.

Sen. Dick Durbin (D-IL), the ranking Democrat on the Senate Appropriations defense subcommittee, said last week on the Senate floor the Pentagon needs to be more "upfront" with Congress about the costs of developmental weapon systems.

"Right now, every weapon system -- every single one of them -- is sold to Congress with a rosy scenario: technological breakthroughs at a modest cost," he said Aug 21. "There is no difference between the sales pitch on a program that is easy to develop and one that is a giant risk."

Durbin said he has been told by Michael Griffin, who operates as the Pentagon's chief innovation officer, DOD officials are risk-averse because they fear bad headlines and testy congressional hearings.

"He said that many members of the Department of Defense are afraid to be the last to say 'yes' to a program that may not succeed," Durbin said. "If something goes wrong, failures are the subject of heated congressional hearings. We have seen that over and over -- from $20,000 toilet seats and similar scandals in the past."

Durbin, however, pointed out that congressional appropriators approved a record $95 billion for defense research and development in fiscal year 2019 -- the highest level in history, even when adjusted for inflation.

"Very often, the contentious hearings that Dr. Griffin spoke about are not the result of a failed test, but a broken promise," Durbin said.

Philip Anton, a RAND Corp. analyst who previously served as deputy director of DOD's Acquisition Policy Analysis Center, said lawmakers will be "tested" as to whether they truly want the Pentagon to move faster, take bigger risks and pursue leap-ahead technology to offset gains made by China and Russia.

"At some point, you can't get it both ways," he said. "It's still acquisition, it's still bleeding edge, there are still going to be issues that crop up."

Still, Anton stressed that many 804 supporters say rapid prototyping will expose and "burn down" risk early enough in a program for acquisition executives to terminate it, rather than authorize programs built around unproven technologies that could lead to catastrophic failures, like the Army's Future Combat Systems effort.

"Be aggressive about it," Anton advised. "If the technology didn't work in the prototype, kill it. Don't wait. Hopefully, the prudence will be there."

That "prudence" involves a data collection and analytics strategy currently being discussed at the Pentagon.

Alan Shaffer, nominated to be deputy under secretary of defense for acquisition and sustainment, told the Senate Armed Services Committee in answers to advance policy questions that "maintaining visibility" into 804 prototyping would be vital to ensure the authority is properly used.

"I understand that USD(A&S) is currently working with the military departments and military services and other users of the 804 authority to develop a data collection and analytic process that will enable the department to have insight into how these projects are being managed and executed," he wrote.

USD A&S Ellen Lord released interim guidance in April encouraging the use of section 804, and military services have followed suit. Final implementation guidance is expected in January that may contain additional details on DOD's 804 oversight structure.

'Cultural change' required

Maryann Watson, an administrator at DAU, has begun efforts to train and educate DOD's acquisition program managers on how to use section 804.

She said the video Roper and Jette made "really shows that senior leaders have given a lot of thought to the value of this and how they approach it so they don't lose the authority."

Watson said she would be interested to see how "creative" program managers are able to be in applying 804.

"There's a great deal of potential," she said. "Hopefully, it will free up people to think differently about what they're allowed to do and, more importantly, what they're encouraged to do."

Lynne Giordano, professor of acquisition management at DAU, said one of the key features of the authority is that it allows program managers to start with a "blank sheet of paper" and add existing aspects of federal acquisition regulation as needed, rather than start with DOD's massive set of regulations and tailor them down.

Giordano said, however, that successful use of 804 would require "cultural change" in the department and Congress.

"It's what happens when there is that first failure," she said. "Because they are saying they are trying to move to the left and do the hard things first."

Shaffer told the Senate Armed Services Committee that, if confirmed to be Lord's deputy, he would encourage "speed to field," while practicing proper risk management through rapid prototyping.

"One thing that I believe is that advanced technology adds cost, schedule, and performance risk," he wrote. "The bigger the technology advancement, the greater the risk. The crux of this question, I believe, is how should defense senior leaders think about and accept risk to allow greater technological advancement. This would represent a cultural change. However, I believe that more use of prototyping allow[s] greater technology advancement while retiring risk. If confirmed, I will advocate for more prototypes to support both introducing advanced technology into future weapons systems while reducing risk." -- Tony Bertuca

urn:contentItem:5T4H-RR41-DY0P-G298-00000-00Pentagon turns to rapid prototyping, hoping for big tech gains, but accepting new risks2018-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisPentagon turns to rapid prototyping, hoping for big tech gains, but accepting new risks

August 27, 2018 | Tony Bertuca Pentagon acquisition executives have begun using a new rapid prototyping and fielding authority that could streamline traditional weapon system development, but might also test the patience of Congress should it lead to costly failures.

The new authority, which has generated significant buzz within the Defense Department's acquisition community, comes from section 804 of the Fiscal Year 2016 National Defense Authorization Act.

Section 804 provides DOD a pathway to accelerate rapid prototyping for "middle tier capabilities" that can be fielded within five years or use proven technologies to upgrade existing systems. Perhaps most importantly, programs operating under 804 authority are allowed to bypass the Joint Requirements Oversight Council and the Joint Capabilities Integration Development System, oversight bodies that critics say slow the acquisition process.

Air Force acquisition chief Will Roper, the former director of the Strategic Capabilities Office, has positioned his service as the leading user of the new authority, earlier this month employing 804 to launch development of the Air-Launched Rapid Response weapon and the Next-Generation Overhead Persistent Infrared satellite constellation.

In a promotional video for Defense Acquisition University, Roper said Air Force program managers are well aware of his affinity for section 804.

"They have quickly realized that I love 804, and I do not like traditional acquisition plans that I'm not going to see complete within the next decade," he said. "They have quickly realized don't bring in traditional acquisition and they have all realigned program plans around 804."

In July, Inside Defense obtained a list of programs the Air Force and the other services told Congress they are considering for 804 authority.

Along with the two programs begun earlier this month, the Air Force is contemplating using 804 for the B-52 Commercial Engine Replacement Program, the new light-attack aircraft, F-22 modernization and protected tactical enterprise services.

Roper said in the DAU video that if there is a developmental program that "doesn't naturally lend itself to this authority, I haven't found it yet."

Bruce Jette, the Army's acquisition chief, also appeared in the DAU video and said his service wants "product, not process" and is "looking very hard" at using section 804 for the Future Vertical Lift program as well as some systems for directed energy, air defense and small missiles.

"Part of this is culture," he said. "Don't get perfect. Where's the good break point? Let's see what we can do in five years."

Critics warn of risks

But Frank Kendall, the former under secretary of defense for acquisition, technology and logistics, said the new rapid prototyping authorities won't eliminate the complexities of technology development.

"What determines how long a development program takes is the product," he told Inside Defense. "Complexity and technical difficulty drive schedule. That can't be wished away. Requirements set by operators drive both complexity and technical difficulty. You have to begin there."

Kendall said it is possible to build some kinds of prototypes quickly if requirements are reduced and designs are simplified.

"Whether an operator will want that product is another question," he said. "It's also possible to set totally unrealistic schedules and get industry to bid on them. There is a great deal of history that teaches us that this is a really bad idea."

Andrew Hunter, an analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies who previously ran the Pentagon's Joint Rapid Acquisition Cell, said he understands the appeal of section 804.

"Section 804 authority clearly provides an alternative path in the acquisition system that exempts programs from many of the existing rules," he said. "For this reason, it is appealing to those looking to streamline acquisition oversight and accelerate the initiation of development programs."

Like Kendall, however, Hunter said 804 authority is unlikely to alter the difficulty of technology development or the inherent need for trade-offs.

"Putting the priority on delivering capability faster means compromising to some extent on one or more other traditional acquisition priorities such as unit cost, performance or sustainability," he said.

Hunter added that there aren't clear program oversight rules for section 804.

"That is similar to the situation with [other transaction authority] where anything is possible, but the very lack of established rules means only a small cadre of experts currently feel comfortable using them," he said. "I think, over time, the flexibility of section 804 authority will likely prove its particular value for certain kinds of development efforts, and a body of newer oversight mechanisms will develop optimized for those efforts."

Wooing Congress

Because 804 is such a new tool, it has yet to be tested with one of the most powerful audiences -- Congress.

Though lawmakers voted to include 804 in the FY-16 NDAA and have frequently pushed for faster defense acquisition, the Pentagon has yet to use 804 it in a meaningful way that leads to what most technology developers say is inevitable and, in many cases, desirable: failure.

"Let's see what happens when they go before Congress with a $500 million failure and say, 'Boy, we sure learned a lot,'" said one former senior DOD official.

Sen. Dick Durbin (D-IL), the ranking Democrat on the Senate Appropriations defense subcommittee, said last week on the Senate floor the Pentagon needs to be more "upfront" with Congress about the costs of developmental weapon systems.

"Right now, every weapon system -- every single one of them -- is sold to Congress with a rosy scenario: technological breakthroughs at a modest cost," he said Aug 21. "There is no difference between the sales pitch on a program that is easy to develop and one that is a giant risk."

Durbin said he has been told by Michael Griffin, who operates as the Pentagon's chief innovation officer, DOD officials are risk-averse because they fear bad headlines and testy congressional hearings.

"He said that many members of the Department of Defense are afraid to be the last to say 'yes' to a program that may not succeed," Durbin said. "If something goes wrong, failures are the subject of heated congressional hearings. We have seen that over and over -- from $20,000 toilet seats and similar scandals in the past."

Durbin, however, pointed out that congressional appropriators approved a record $95 billion for defense research and development in fiscal year 2019 -- the highest level in history, even when adjusted for inflation.

"Very often, the contentious hearings that Dr. Griffin spoke about are not the result of a failed test, but a broken promise," Durbin said.

Philip Anton, a RAND Corp. analyst who previously served as deputy director of DOD's Acquisition Policy Analysis Center, said lawmakers will be "tested" as to whether they truly want the Pentagon to move faster, take bigger risks and pursue leap-ahead technology to offset gains made by China and Russia.

"At some point, you can't get it both ways," he said. "It's still acquisition, it's still bleeding edge, there are still going to be issues that crop up."

Still, Anton stressed that many 804 supporters say rapid prototyping will expose and "burn down" risk early enough in a program for acquisition executives to terminate it, rather than authorize programs built around unproven technologies that could lead to catastrophic failures, like the Army's Future Combat Systems effort.

"Be aggressive about it," Anton advised. "If the technology didn't work in the prototype, kill it. Don't wait. Hopefully, the prudence will be there."

That "prudence" involves a data collection and analytics strategy currently being discussed at the Pentagon.

Alan Shaffer, nominated to be deputy under secretary of defense for acquisition and sustainment, told the Senate Armed Services Committee in answers to advance policy questions that "maintaining visibility" into 804 prototyping would be vital to ensure the authority is properly used.

"I understand that USD(A&S) is currently working with the military departments and military services and other users of the 804 authority to develop a data collection and analytic process that will enable the department to have insight into how these projects are being managed and executed," he wrote.

USD A&S Ellen Lord released interim guidance in April encouraging the use of section 804, and military services have followed suit. Final implementation guidance is expected in January that may contain additional details on DOD's 804 oversight structure.

'Cultural change' required

Maryann Watson, an administrator at DAU, has begun efforts to train and educate DOD's acquisition program managers on how to use section 804.

She said the video Roper and Jette made "really shows that senior leaders have given a lot of thought to the value of this and how they approach it so they don't lose the authority."

Watson said she would be interested to see how "creative" program managers are able to be in applying 804.

"There's a great deal of potential," she said. "Hopefully, it will free up people to think differently about what they're allowed to do and, more importantly, what they're encouraged to do."

Lynne Giordano, professor of acquisition management at DAU, said one of the key features of the authority is that it allows program managers to start with a "blank sheet of paper" and add existing aspects of federal acquisition regulation as needed, rather than start with DOD's massive set of regulations and tailor them down.

Giordano said, however, that successful use of 804 would require "cultural change" in the department and Congress.

"It's what happens when there is that first failure," she said. "Because they are saying they are trying to move to the left and do the hard things first."

Shaffer told the Senate Armed Services Committee that, if confirmed to be Lord's deputy, he would encourage "speed to field," while practicing proper risk management through rapid prototyping.

"One thing that I believe is that advanced technology adds cost, schedule, and performance risk," he wrote. "The bigger the technology advancement, the greater the risk. The crux of this question, I believe, is how should defense senior leaders think about and accept risk to allow greater technological advancement. This would represent a cultural change. However, I believe that more use of prototyping allow[s] greater technology advancement while retiring risk. If confirmed, I will advocate for more prototypes to support both introducing advanced technology into future weapons systems while reducing risk."

urn:contentItem:610K-8KN1-DY4H-K0X1-00000-00People don't trust the facts about Trump's coronavirus. Is it any wonder?2020-10-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisOPINIONVersion:2People don't trust the facts about Trump's coronavirus. Is it any wonder?Simon Jenkins

An unregulated internet was always likely to breed confusion, denial and conspiracy theories. This is its nadir

The president is not really sick. He is very sick. He is pretending. He is not pretending. That was his body double in the car. He may die. The illness is a fake to win Christian sympathy.

To QAnon's followers, Covid is a deep-state Democrat trick to enslave the US and Trump's "illness" is tactical. So don't trust anything any more. We are in a maelstrom of information, spin and lies. No wonder there are six explanations for every apparently simple development.

Doctors have never known how to handle sick leaders. They said Britain's Boris Johnson was just fine and cheerful. When this proved untrue he was said to be dying. Bulletins merged into bullshit. Nothing was believed. Johnson had to bitterly protest his health only this weekend.

When doctors lie about the fitness of leaders it matters to the security of the state. Woodrow Wilson's 1919 flu was critical to the outcome of Versailles. Churchill was ill as prime minister in the 1950s. The tendency now is to reveal all, but as Johnson and Trump show, any crisis is a gift to spin.

Viewers of the Netflix docudrama The Social Dilemma, by the Silicon Valley ethicist Tristan Harris, are appalled at the manipulative behaviour of the big tech giants, and at the billions susceptible to it. Social media is crafted as a colossal edifice of confirmation bias. It is institutionally mendacious.

No holder of liberal values - however defined - can defend the cruel anarchy of the web. We have been taken back to the time of the Salem witches, when an anonymous lie pinned to a church door was known to a whole village in minutes. True, the management of information became the privilege of ecclesiastical, political and commercial power. The profession of journalism evolved into one of mediating, editing, checking, censoring that dissemination. It sought, and to a degree succeeded, in creating trust in news.

That trust has all but collapsed under the barrage of unregulated "platforms". Their capacity for good has failed to match their evil. Even now they are undermining trust in any Covid vaccine. No politician dares curb them. It would be paradoxical if it took the illness of a president to finally subject internet "news" to the same regulation as has long disciplined the mainstream media. This must happen. The great editor in the sky must prevail. But how many witches will die first?

An old maxim holds that news is only as valid as its source. The advent of instant digital communication was supposed to free the conduits of information to a new age of objective reality, of incorruptible truth. This was rubbish. The internet turned information into something infinitely flexible and made its sources more powerful than ever before. The idea of instant validation and fact-checking defaulted to one of agency - who was checking the checkers? Mark Twain is still right. A lie is halfway round the world when truth is still putting on its boots.

Simon Jenkins is a Guardian columnist

urn:contentItem:5VR3-8FW1-DYTG-N0TG-00000-00PEOPLE NEED TO HAVE MORE POWER OVER THEIR PRIVACY, TECH INDUSTRY LEADER SAYS2019-03-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisHOME NEWSPEOPLE NEED TO HAVE MORE POWER OVER THEIR PRIVACY, TECH INDUSTRY LEADER SAYS

By Jamie Harris, Press Association Science Technology Reporter

The public must be given more power to control their privacy, the leader of a UK technology body has said, as the country moves closer to potential regulation of social networks and big tech firms.

Jacqueline de Rojas, president of techUK, the body representing 900 companies in the digital sector, believes that regulation will only work if decision-makers work together with the industry to bring about changes to the way people's data is used.

``I would like to see much more privacy in the hands of the individual,'' Ms de Rojas told BBC Radio 4's Desert Island Discs.

``We have to, as individuals, also be clear about what we want to have out there, and have complete control over that.

``I think we will need regulation, but I think we need regulation together with the platform providers themselves, because you have got to have that partnership in order to make it work.''

The entrepreneur also spoke about Brexit and stressed the urgency for certainty so tech businesses can prepare.

``We do need to have trade deals in terms of data and we need to have agreements in terms of security but I think perhaps our biggest issue is access to talent,'' she continued.

The Government is preparing to release its white paper on online harms, which is expected to include some form of regulation making social networks more responsible for what is shared on their platforms.

Desert Island Discs is available on BBC Sounds and BBC Radio 4 from 11.15am on Sundays.

AXELROD: Does it sound to you like a prelude to a --

BUSH: When I heard it, I started to think, "Oh, I guess I'm here." I was introducing him and I was honored to be there and I kind of got a sense that maybe this was an opening at least for him to consider it.

AXELROD: Do you think he should run?

BUSH: I think someone should run just because Republicans ought to be given a choice, but I think you're probably right based on the premise you had that he has a strong loyal base and it'd be hard to beat him. It's hard to beat a sitting President. But to have a conversation about what it is to be a conservative, I think it's important and our country needs to have competing ideologies that people - that are dynamic that focus on the world we're in and the world we're moving towards rather than revert back to the nostalgic time.

[18:45:06]

The Democrats now are proposing new ideas, some of which I think are way out there and if Republicans think they can just say that's bad and not offer a compelling alternative, that could be bad for us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CABRERA: David Axelrod is with us now. David, we just heard Jeb Bush say someone should challenge Trump in 2020.

AXELROD: Yes.

CABRERA: You called it a potential suicide mission. So do you think someone actually will? AXELROD: Well, governor Larry Hogan of Maryland was the person we were talking about. He has openly discussed the possibility of challenging President Trump and it sounded very much like Jeb Bush was urging him forward in that race. Ana, I have been trying to get Jeb Bush to sit down with me for quite a while to reflect on his family and his campaign on where the country is and where he thinks it's going. And he was reluctant and then he changed his thinking and said, "I want to sit down."

And he clearly have things on his mind and one of them was that he believes there ought to be a contest for the Republican nomination knowing that President Trump probably would win. But as he said, airing conservative views because he said he doesn't view Trump as a conservative. He doesn't view him as an ideologue. He thinks he's self-interested.

And while Bush said that he agreed with some of the things that Trump did, he had very strong disagreements and he aired them in this discussion.

CABRERA: And I've talked to a number of Trump supporters who will say, "I don't agree with everything that he does, but I like his policies. I believe that he is doing what's best for the country in that realm." In fact, we have a lot of Trump's earliest critics up on Capitol Hill say Senator Lindsey Graham or Senator Ted Cruz who have come around and become some of his staunchest supporters. Will we ever see that from Jeb Bush?

AXELROD: Yes, Jeb, I asked him about this because I hear that a lot from Republican friends. Well, we got tax cuts, we got deregulation, we've got the Conservative judges. So if we have to put up a little incivility perhaps some skirting of the rules and the laws, that's OK.

He was very tough in response to that and offered a real admonition to those who subscribe to that theory that the price is too high to accept even for the things that he agrees with, the price is too high to accept this incivility, to accept this shredding of democratic norms. It seemed to me that was one of the things that he wanted to get off his chest.

CABRERA: Interesting. David Axelrod as always, thank you for being with us.

AXELROD: Good to be with you.

CABRERA: Don't miss The Axe Files tonight at 7:00 Eastern right here on CNN.

[18:50:00]

Parts of the Midwest are dealing with record flooding and bracing for more in the wake of the powerful Bomb Cyclone in addition to the seasonal snow melt. In Nebraska at least 37 people have had to be rescued from floodwaters and many communities across the region remain under flood warnings. The Missouri River is more than two feet above its flooding stage and continues to rise. The new four-part CNN Original Series Tricky Dick explores Richard Nixon's rise, fall, incredible comeback and political destruction featuring never before seen footage. Here's a preview.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RICHARD NIXON, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: When I first met Kennedy was a Congressman. He was very intelligent. He was very personable. However, I sensed that he was very shy and frankly as I was. I rather thought that we were alike in that respect but we were very different in many ways.

He, of course, had all of the money he needed for personal purposes. He'd never had to fight his way up. You never had to worry about losing in a campaign or fear that he wouldn't have a job.

JOHN KENNEDY, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It is time, in short, for a new generation of leadership.

NIXON: He was one that attracted the people who wanted a young, courageous man in the presidency and yet one who is suave, smooth, and a debonair and graceful. Basically, that's the mark of royalty.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CABRERA: Richard Nixon on John F. Kennedy. Make sure you don't miss the premiere of Tricky Dick. It's tomorrow at 9PM Eastern right here on CNN. That does it for me. I'm back in one hour with more today's top stories in the CNN Newsroom. Thanks for being here. Axe Files with David Axelrod is next.

[18:55:00]

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Tonight on The Axe Files. Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush sizing up the Trump presidency.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BUSH: My prayer is that he wakes up someday soon and realizes he's President of the United States. He has to lead for all of us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Reflecting on his 2016 presidential run.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BUSH: You know you move on, I'm out of therapy and back to my normal life.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And who he wants to see on the ballot in 2020.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BUSH: I think someone should run just because Republicans ought to be given a choice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Plus, his famous family's legacy and coping with the loss of his parents.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BUSH: There was kind of a consensus that this was a bygone era. This was the end of an era.

AXELROD: I want to ask about that, yes.

BUSH: And that's wrong.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Welcome to The Axe Files.

AXELROD: Governor Bush, good to be with you here at the Biltmore Hotel, the stately Biltmore Hotel.

BUSH: Thanks for coming down.

AXELROD: ... storied history. Great to come down. So it's that season again, everybody is lining up to run for president. Any PTSD.

BUSH: Yes. I mean it's deja vu all over again. If you're a political junkie, I guess it's kind of fun to watch.

[19:00:02]

AXELROD: Not so much if you're a candidate.

BUSH: No, if you're a candidate, it's a little bit harder.

AXELROD: What advice you have for them?
