urn:contentItem:4J9N-SBX0-TX4V-S1YC-00000-00Peter Nowak: Lies and damn lies, look who's talking2006-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYGeneralPeter Nowak: Lies and damn lies, look who's talking

The knives have come out in the battle of broadband, and embattled Telecom is seeing a few allies come to its aid. There's no doubt the company needs them, but as the old adage goes, with friends like these, who needs enemies?

One such ally, Macquarie Research Equities, may actually be hurting Telecom's cause. The stock brokerage last week issued an embarrassing report titled "Lies and damn lies" that took shots at the media, labelling coverage of Telecom as "factually incorrect", "misleading" and "biased".

The brokerage hadn't taken Telecom's negative press seriously before, but now - with the Prime Minister sounding off on the country's poor broadband situation - "the risks have risen".

"The media attack on Telecom seems to be having the political impact desired by Telecom's competitors," the report says.

It's not the trite line taken by Macquarie that's embarrassing for the brokerage, it's the report's suggestion that all is well in New Zealand broadband. And even more worrying, for investors at least, is the suggestion that all is well with Telecom's stock.

Neither of these claims has the slightest grounding in reality.

New Zealand's broadband woes are well documented. We're 22nd out of 30 in OECD uptake, and that's that. Slow speeds, high prices, data limits and access problems have all contributed to Kiwis' low interest in broadband.

But those problems are just window dressing. The real point is that New Zealand will continue to wallow as long as one company is allowed to control speeds and pricing, and thus the entire market.

That's not just the sentiment of Telecom's rivals such as TelstraClear or ihug, it's what everyone - from the big tech firms to economists to small businesses to home users - is saying.

But according to Macquarie, "apart from a couple of issues (upload speeds and business DSL pricing), NZ in fact compares well to both its closest neighbour Australia and to other similar countries".

The average Kiwi consumer, Macquarie says, "is better off than their Australian counterpart, despite popular claims to the contrary".

The comparison with Australia is absurd. It was only a year ago that Australia ranked just as poorly as New Zealand in the OECD uptake statistics, at 21st place.

The country is in the midst of unbundling incumbent Telstra's network to allow rivals access, and with stronger wholesale regulations than we enjoy, it has since managed to improve its situation somewhat, moving to 17th place.

But make no mistake - Australia is still as big a loser in the global broadband stakes as New Zealand. And with Telstra playing wholesale hardball as of late, it wouldn't be at all surprising to see the country take a step backward in uptake rankings over the next little while.

Macquarie's report doesn't make any comparisons with other countries, basically because it can't.

New Zealand's speeds and prices are laughable when matched to any of the top 10 countries, so comparing ourselves with Australia is not exactly aiming high.

This is especially true if you compare stock performance. While Telecom's stock has dropped 15 per cent over the past year, Telstra has plummeted 23 per cent, making it one of the worst-performing telco stocks in the world. Given that Telstra is so ingrained in Australia's broadband situation, is this really a company whose lead we want to be following?

But the brokerage is somehow confident the New Zealand Government will come to its senses, see there really isn't anything wrong with broadband here, and leave regulation alone. Macquarie is thus still bullish on Telecom's stock, with a 12-month price target of $6.40.

However, with the company's stock trading in the $5.50 range, that's an overly optimistic forecast, especially when non-regulatory issues are taken into account - something the report conveniently omits entirely.

Incumbent telco stocks are dropping worldwide - Deutsche Telekom is down 16 per cent over the past year, France Telecom 20 per cent, Spain's Telefonica 15 per cent and Bell Canada 7 per cent. Those are just a few examples.

That's primarily because their traditional revenues are on the decline thanks to lower-cost internet-based calling - a fact Telecom itself has acknowledged. The big telcos are still trying to figure out how to transform their businesses in the face of new and disruptive technologies, and most are struggling to do so.

Interestingly, the exceptions to the rule seem to be the ones taking proactive measures. British Telecom, which voluntarily agreed to separate its wholesale and retail arms, has seen its stock resist the trend and remain flat over the past year. US telcos have generally seen their stocks improve, largely due to recent merger activity.

Add this global trend to a possible downturn in the New Zealand economy and a worsening dollar, and it's very hard to be bullish on Telecom's stock.

The Government's decision on regulation will ultimately come down to Telecom's stock concerns versus the public good. Given the realities, for Macquarie to accuse the media of being misleading seems pretty foolish. The brokerage should be very careful of who it's accusing of lies and damn lies.

Peterson Institute For International Economics And Princeton University Holds Discussion On The Future Of Money In The Digital Age

October 16, 2019 03:00 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF NEW YORK'S MARKETS GROUP FORMER EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT SIMON POTTER

FINANCIAL TIMES CHIEF ECONOMICS COMMENTATOR MARTIN WOLF

RIKSBANK GOVERNOR STEFAN INGVES

BANK FOR INTERNATIONAL SETTLEMENTS RESEARCH HEAD HYUN SONG SHIN

PRINCETON UNIVERSITYBENDHEIM CENTER FOR FINANCE DIRECTOR MARKUS BRUNNERMEIER

BOARD OF GOVERNORS OF THE FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM MEMBER LAEL BRAINARD

PETERSON INSTITUTE PRESIDENT ADAM POSEN

[*]POSEN: Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us again today at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. I'm Adam Posen, the institute's president. I'm always proud to host events here with distinguished friends and officials. And sometimes people are both friends and officials.

But I am particularly proud to be hosting today--co-hosting actually--with the Bendheim Center for Finance at Princeton and my friend, and colleague, Markus Brunnermeier.

We are at the cutting edge, I guess, by having some of the world's leading central bankers and leading monetary thinkers come to speak about money, the future of money, in the digital age. And of course, we're also joined by a rockstar in the form of Martin Wolf.

We are delighted to be doing this particularly, obviously, this week when so many senior officials and people and markets are in town, and we're grateful to our friends who joined us today. In particular, I want to thank Frank Brosens who, of Taconic Finance, who is a member of our Board of Directors, and a member of--I want to make sure I get the title right--The Advisory Panel, I believe it is--of The Bendheim--Advisory Counsel of The Bendheim Center for Finance--one of the most brilliant, real minds in finance.

I'm grateful to Frank, not because he just has such excellent taste in institutions, but because he gave the nudge to Markus and I to actually come together. And so, in many ways we always talked, but we hadn't come to anything. So, we're grateful to Frank which gave fruition to this.

We are starting on a more timely schedule than usual partly because it's this week, and partly because we are grateful and proud to, once again, welcome back Lael Brainard, a member of the Board of Governors of The Federal Reserve System, to the stage, here, at the Peterson Institute.

This is the point, with this crowd on this topic, where Governor Brainard needs no introduction. She has been a member of the Board of Governors with The Fed in--since June of 2014. She previously served as undersecretary at The U.S. Department of Treasury from 2010 to 2013, and Counselor to the Secretary of the Treasury in 2009.

In short, she has been the leading U.S. official on matters of international finance, from both the Treasury and the Federal Reserve side of the street for many years now--showed extraordinary leadership in--during the crisis, during issues of G7 and G20 management.

I always cite her--her incredible work in getting the currency piece, which we have enjoyed since late 2012, which I think her leadership played an enormous role in. And obviously, in recent years, as part of her work and public service with The Federal Reserve Board, has been a leading light on innovation and regulation and the growth effects of finance.

And we are very honored to have her with us today. I will invite her to speak in just a moment. Just to say again that this is a jam-packed, full, substantive event. We not only have Governor Brainard and then we'll be taking questions from Markus and I, and then from the floor to her, as her schedule allows.

Then we'll be turning to a new paper presented by Professor Brunnermeier, co-authored with Harold James of Princeton, who I am glad to see is with us today, and Jean-Pierre Landau of Science Po, on how digitalization will transform the role of money.

We also have--we have available, for everyone on the website, and in print, this new paper, The Digitalization of Money by Brunnermeier, James, Landau. We also have a number of short pieces written by the usual thousand flowers of thought at the Peterson Institute that I encourage you also to read.

Finally, we will have a superstar panel moderated by Martin Wolf, the Chief Economics Commentator and Editor of The Financial Times, with Governor Stefan Ingves of the RiksBank, which is on the cutting edge of these technologies, Simon Potter of the Peterson Institute now, formerly of the New York Federal Reserve, who we're delighted to have with us, and probably the most brilliant mind in finance I know, even allowing for Markus, Hyung Song Shin, from the Bank for International Settlements.

So, this is a spectacular group. Thank you all for joining us. And may I invite Governor Brainard to the stage.

(APPLAUSE)

BRAINARD: Wow! Thank you to Adam for a very kind introduction. And it's always a pleasure to be here at Peterson.

There's a long history of technological advances challenging the prevailing notions of money, from the trading of coins to the use of paper currency to the electronic debiting and crediting of funds on the accounts of banks.

Today, efforts by Stablecoin networks, such as Facebook's Libra, to establish the next chapter in the story of money are raising threshold questions about legal and regulatory safeguards, financial stability, and monetary policy.

Because of its potential global reach, Facebook's Libra imparts urgency to the debate over what form money can take, who or what can issue it, and how payments can be recorded and settled.

A decade ago, Bitcoin was heralded as a new kind of digital currency that would provide the three functions of money without the need for centralized governance. Bitcoin's emergence created an entirely new payment instrument, and asset class, exchanged over a set of payment rails supported by distributed ledger technology, a shared tamper-resistant ledger that can be updated by anyone with sufficient compute power.

But Bitcoin did not achieve widespread acceptance as a means of payment, or unit of account, due to its extreme volatility, as well as limited throughput, unpredictable transactions costs limited-to-no governance and limited transparency.

Stablecoins were designed specifically to overcome the volatility of the first-generation cryptocurrencies that limited their utility in payments and as a unit of account. As their name is intended to convey, Stablecoin's aim to maintain stable value by tying the digital currency to an asset, or a basket of assets, such as commercial bank deposits or government issued bonds.

Unlike first generation cryptocurrencies, they may be issued by a central entity and rely on third party institutions for some aspects. Just as any currency's value, as a medium of exchange, increases with the size of the network using it. So, too, the power of the Stablecoin payment system depends on its ability to achieve widespreaded option.

In light of the 2.7 billion active, monthly users on Facebook's platforms, the Libra Stablecoin Project stands out for the speed with which its network could reach global scale in payments.

To provide context for assessing Stablecoins, it's useful to understand established arrangements for the Issuance Regulation and transfer of money.

Central bank money and commercial bank money are the foundations of the modern financial system. Central bank money, physical cash, and money held in deposits at a central bank, represents a safe settlement asset, allowing users to exchange central bank liabilities with confidence in their acceptance and reliability. In addition, central banks play a critical role, as providers of liquidity, at times of stress by lending central bank money.

Money held in deposits at commercial banks is widely used because people are confident that they can convert it on demand for the liability of another commercial bank, or the central bank, such as physical cash. This is because bank deposits are insured. And commercial banks are subject to supervision, regulation, and deposit insurance requirements.

Non-bank private money, or assets, can also facilitate transactions among a network of users. In some cases, such as airline miles, such assets may have value only within that network. In other cases, the issuer may guarantee convertibility to a sovereign currency, such that it becomes a liability of the issuer.

In those cases, customers trust that the company issuing such money will be able to honor those liabilities. Many U.S. consumers experience non-bank private money already in the form of gift cards, loyalty points, and virtual gaming currencies. For instance, Starbucks report it had 1.6 billion in stored-value card liabilities towards the end of last year, which is more than the deposits of many banks.

As the scale and scope of such private networks grow, so too, do the convenience, and benefit of transacting within the network. These network benefits may be augmented by the active use of network data for a host of purposes from allocating and pricing credit, to sharing reviews to prioritizing information that is pushed to users.

In China, consumers and businesses participate in two mobile networks, Alipay and WeChat Pay, which by some accounts handled more than 37 trillion in mobile payments last year. These networks operate within China, based on the RMB, as the unit of account and balances are transferable in and out of bank, or credit card accounts.

Stablecoins may represent private, non-bank liabilities, depending on their design and claim structure. They aspire to achieve the functions of traditional money, without relying on confidence in an issuer, such as a central bank, to stand behind the money.

Indeed, for some potential Stablecoins, a close assessment suggests users may have no rights with respect to the underlying assets, or the system overall.

We've already seen the growth of massive payments networks on existing digital platforms, such as Ali--Alibaba and WeChat, and the issuance of Stablecoins on a smaller scale, such as Tether, Gemini, and Pacsis.

What sets Facebook's Libra apart is the combination of an active user network representing more than a third of the global population with the issuance of a private, digital currency opaquely tied to a basket of sovereign currencies.

It should be no surprise that Facebook's Libra is attracting a high level of scrutiny from law makers and authorities. Libra, like any global, Stablecoin project, must address a core set of legal and regulatory challenges, before it can facilitate a first payment.

Let me touch on a few of these. First, compliance with know your customer regulations are essential, if Stablecoins are not to be used for illegal activities and illicit finance.

Libra's business model is inherently cross-border, and as such, each participant in the system that is a financial institution would need to ensure compliance with each jurisdiction's anti-money laundering laws. Libra's intended global reach would likely necessitate a global--a consistent global anti-money laundering framework, in order to reduce the risk of illicit transactions.

Second, issuers of Stablecoin's design to facilitate consumer payments must clearly demonstrate how consumers would be protected. Consumers will need to be educated on how their rights differ with respect to digital wallets, compared with bank accounts.

Statutory and regulatory protections on bank accounts mean that consumers can reasonably expect their deposits to be insured up to a limit, fraudulent transactions to be the liability of the bank, transfers to be available within specified periods, and clear standardized disclosures about account fees and interest payments.

Not only is it not clear whether comparable protections would be in place in a Stablecoin network, such as Libra, or what recourse consumers would have, but it isn't even clear how much price risk consumers will face since they don't appear to have rights to the underlying assets.

The large number of cyber breaches in the last few years highlight the importance of getting clarity on what legal entity can be held responsible for the security of personally identifiable information and transactions data, and how personal data will be stored, accessed, and used.

Third, it'll be necessary to define the financial activities the various players in the ecosystem are conducting, in order for jurisdictions to assess whether existing regulatory and enforcement mechanisms, are adequate.

Switzerland is the legal domicile of the Labor Associations. And in Switzerland, there are three new categories to facilitate their approach of regulating by function.

Payment tokens are cryptocurrencies that are meant for use in payments or value transfers, utility tokens are block-chain based applications, and asset tokens are cryptocurr--crypto assets that are analogous to equities, bonds and derivatives.

Here in the U.S., regulators are closely examining particular Stablecoins and cryptocurrencies to determine whether, and where, they fit in the regulatory structure, and whether additional authorities, or guidance, is necessary. Our market regulators have authorities for products judged to be securities, or commodity futures, under relevant law.

At the state level, the New York State Department of Financial Services has established a Bit License for virtual currencies.

The Federal Reserve, and the other federal banking agencies, have supervisory authority over banks, but the Federal Reserve does not have plenary authority over payment systems operating in the U.S.

The FSOC does have the authority to designate systemically important non-bank financial companies, financial market utilities, or payment-clearing and settlement activities, based on the facts on the specific situation.

It isn't clear at this time, whether any cryptocurrency issuer, would meet the statutory requirements for FSOC designation.

Fourth, the distributed ledger technology underlying many Stablecoins, and cryptocurrencies more generally, have advantages, but they also have risks. While they could offer advantages by enhancing operational resilience, increasing transparency, and simplifying recordkeeping, the public and immutable nature of the transactions ledger, also introduces risks, such as data privacy concerns, and legal complexity.

Fifth, widespread mitigation to one or more global Stablecoin networks could disintermediate banks, if consumers and businesses reduce their deposits at commercial banks in favor of Stablecoins held in digital wallets. This could shrink bank sources of stable funding, as well as their visibility into transactions data, and thereby hinder their ability to provide credit to businesses and households.

That said, many banks are likely to adapt by offering alternative methods of pure to pure settlement, and by incorporating Stablecoins into their business models, whether by partnering with Fintech firms who are issuing Stablecoins, or by issuing their own, as some are already doing.

Sixth, widespread adoption of Stablecoins could have implications for the role of central banks and for monetary policy. Large-scale migration into a new Stablecoin network for purposes of payments may prove to be the leading edge of a broader migration that encompasses the other functions of money.

If a large share of domestic households and businesses migrate to a global Stablecoin, not only as a means of payment, but also as a store of value, this could shrink demand for physical cash and affect the size of the central bank's balance sheet, and the central bank's approach to implementing monetary policy.

These effects are likely to be more significant for small, open economies, or those with weak monetary institutions, or the migration away from the sovereign currency to a global Stablecoin could weaken the scope for independent monetary policy through a process that's the digital analog of dollarization.

Large-scale Stablecoin use could also affect larger, advanced economies with extensive connections to the global financial system, by increasing market volatility and transmitting shocks across borders.

And finally, a Stablecoin network with global reach raises financial stability considerations. If not managed effectively, liquidity, credit, market, or operational risks, alone or in combination, could trigger a loss of confidence and run behavior.

This could be exacerbated by a lack of clarity about the management of reserves and the rights and responsibilities of various market participants in the network. The risks and spillovers could be amplified by potential ambiguity surrounding the ability of official authorities to provide oversight, backstop liquidity, and collaborate across borders.

Even before the advent of Stablecoin to some jurisdictions, a pronounced migration from cash to digital payments had already prompted central banks to explore the merits and risks of moving to digital issuance of their own currencies.

The potential for global Stablecoin systems has intensified the interest in central bank, digital currencies. Proponents argue that central bank, digital currencies would be a safer alternative to privately issued Stablecoins because they'd be a direct liability of the central bank.

And you're going to hear later today, from Markus Brunnermeier, about his paper, which provides important arguments in this arena.

Of course, the Federal Reserve, and other central banks, already provide money digitally in the form of central bank deposits in traditional reserve, or settlement accounts. However, in the current context, central bank digital currency, typically, refers to a new type of central bank liability that could be held directly by households and businesses, without the involvement of a commercial bank intermediary.

Such central bank digital currencies could differ from traditional reserves along three dimensions. A much broader set of institutions and individuals could access it, some types of balances might not pay interest, and it might entail greater government visibility into end users, or consumer's transactions.

In the United States, there are compelling advantages to the system that we have today. First, physical cash in circulation for the U.S. dollar continues to rise, suggesting there is robust demand.

Second, the dollar is an important reserve currency globally, and maintaining public trust in our currency is paramount.

Third, we have a robust and diverse banking system that meets the needs of consumers.

And finally, we have a widely available and expanding variety of digital payment options that build on the existing institutional framework, and the applicable safeguards.

Central bank digital currency for general purpose use, that is for individual consumer use, would raise profound legal policy and operational questions. Let's consider the balance between privacy and guarding against illicit activity.

If it's designed to provide safeguards against illicit activity, a central bank digital currency for consumer use could conceivably require the central bank to keep a running record of all payments data using the digital currency, a stark difference from cash.

A system in which individual payments information would be recorded by a government entity would mark a dramatic shift. A related question is whether the Federal Reserve even has the authority to issue currency in digital form, and if necessary, to establish digital wallets for the public.

There could also be profound monetary implications. Some economists have argued, probably in this room, that a central bank-- digital currency could address the problems posed by the zero-lower bound, by transmitting monetary policy directly to the public.

Executing monetary policy in such a manner could imply the elimination of all physical cash and the power to impose a negative rate, or a tax, on household's holdings of digital money. Those represent dramatic changes.

My own strong preference is to address the effective lower-bound by using our existing tool kit vigorously, since I view the cost benefit assessment of negative rates as unattractive for the current U.S. context.

Financial stability considerations are also important. The ability to convert commercial bank deposits into central bank digital currency with a simple swipe, surely has the potential to be a run accelerant.

And finally, there could be operational risks to a central bank digital bank currency. For starters, this might require the Federal Reserve to develop the operating capacity to access, or manage, individual accounts which could number in the hundreds of millions.

A myriad of op--other operational challenges would need to be addressed, including electronic counterfeiting, and cyber risks.

That said, some jurisdictions may move in this direction faster than others, based on the particular attributes of their payments and currency systems. The Federal Reserve, we will continue to analyze the potential benefits and costs of central bank digital currencies, and look forward to learning from our colleagues.

While prudence cautions against rushing into untested approaches to central bank digital currencies, we are actively investing in our payments infrastructure so that everyone has access to real-time payments.

We announced that we'll launch the first new payment system in more than 40 years, to help make real--real-time payments available to everyone. FedNow will provide a platform for consumers and businesses to send and receive payments immediately and securely 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year.

It will provide a platform that's neutral for private sector innovation in new faster payment services for in-users, and we're also exploring enhancements to--FedWire Fund Service and National Settlement Services, including expanding office operating hours.

As the public and private sectors work to reduce payments frictions, one of the most important use cases is for cross-border payments, such as remittances. Technology enables ecommerce to transcend national borders, but current cross-border payment solutions are slow, cumbersome, and opaque.

Authorities in many jurisdictions, including the U.S., recognize the importance of cooperating across borders with each other, and the private sector, to address these con--these considerable cross-border frictions.

No doubt, technology will continue driving rapid change in the way we make payments and the concept of money. The Federal Reserve remains confident in the power of technology and innovation to transform the financial system and reduce frictions while, also, preserving the important consumer protections, data privacy and security, financial stability, and monetary policy transmission mechanisms that have built up, over many decades.

Given the stakes, global Stablecoin network should be expected to meet a high threshold of legal and regulatory safeguards, before launching operations.

We are monitoring new technologies closely, with respect to the implications for our operational responsibilities and broader public policy goals, and we are open to exploring new possibilities.

We are upgrading our services to support innovation of payments, and we will continue to work to foster a safe and efficient payment system including where money, in all its myriad forms, present and future, is concerned. Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

POSEN: The middle seat at the table--

BRAINARD: Sure.

POSEN: --or would you rather stand?

BRAINARD: Either one.

POSEN: What?

BRAINARD: Either way. Which do you prefer?

POSEN: Why don't you stand?

BRAINARD: Ok.

POSEN: If you will.

Governor Brainard has kindly consented to take questions on the record. I'll play traffic cop, if needed, but I'd like to recognize Professor Brunnermeier to make the first comment or question, as he chooses.

QUESTION: I'll just ask one question quickly. I was struck, actually, by Starbucks, you mentioned example, that they're 1.6 billion, in terms of liabilities to customers, in terms of credit cards, to let--or in terms of gift cards.

If Starbucks were to decide to make--to liquefy these liabilities, what requirements do you have any idea, when the Fed would step in, or how would it intervene? At what point would it intervene by saying, "Ok, you can freely transfer this--cash you have on--for Starbucks liabilities from one customer to next customer, you pay with your friends and all this."

Would the Fed be concerned at this dimension, as well?

BRAINARD: So, I think in--in the case, in the particular case, it's a--it's a closed network. And I--it's really the liabilities of a particular legal entity to a network of users that have signed up for it. So, in that sense, it's more like a prepaid card. And we do actually have pretty good--even--as of recently, even better guard rails around prepaid cards, but that's conceptually how I would think about it. That's the closest analog.

POSEN: Just the quick--just the quick ground rules. When you're recognized, please feel free to speak. The more your comment resembles a question, the longer you can go, and vice versa.

(LAUGHTER)

Please identify yourself when speaking. Since the Governor's on the record, so should you be.

There is a traveling mic, which Patricia will bring you and there's a standing mic in the back.

BRAINARD: I would just amend that to say feel free to filibuster.

POSEN: Oh!

(LAUGHTER)

POSEN: Not something I expected her to say. Always surprising. Actually, next in line, though, is Martin Wolf.

QUESTION: Sir Martin Wolf from the Financial--Financial Times. I am--two questions, very simple, I think. I--but not perhaps to answer.

The first is, in the U.S. case, how far do you think you need changes in law governing the regulatory structure to actually manage all the problems you indicate with these new players?

And the second thing is, in particular, do you have the powers to determine whether specific organizations making radical proposals for a transformation of the system? Let's say Facebook is actually a suitable organization to do any of this, because some of us think that's a pretty big issue.

BRAINARD: So those are good questions. I laid out a little bit earlier, the regulatory authorities that we do have across different regulatory bodies in the U.S., and the way that they are currently configured, and the extent to which they may be applicable, or they may be potentially, insufficiently broad, in some cases.

And licensing authority, in particular, you know our authority at the Fed is quite narrow. We really have oversight over certain supervised banks.

As I said earlier, we do not have plenary authority over payment systems, which I think is a very important point. FSOC authority is a question mark because it is going to depend on the very specific facts and circumstances, and it's really with regard to financial institutions and financial activities.

So, the reality is that those regulatory authorities may, or may not be adequate, depending on how this entity and other entities decide to constitute themselves legally, which I think is still evolving and a little unclear.

With regard to your second question, which is also a very important question, we really don't have that kind of authority. And so, it would really lie elsewhere.

The other point, which I think is implicit in your questions, is any of these entities that start from day one with global scope and global scale require a tremendous amount of cross-border cooperation among various regulatory authorities in different jurisdictions.

And each jurisdiction has different licensing authorities and different regulatory parameters, and that is one of the reasons that the G7 is spending a lot of time on this. This is something where we are at the FSB working a lot on this. It is inherently going to require a lot of cross-border cooperation with sets of rules that are quite different in different jurisdictions.

POSEN: Thank you. Next, if there are questions.

QUESTION: Thank you, very much. James Faucette from Morgan Stanley. I had, I guess, two questions, to a little bit dovetail on your previous response.

I guess, and maybe the impossible question, but how do you manage and work through the coordination of--of across all the different entities, both internal and internationally, particularly when, for the large technology companies, has become somewhat in vogue as they go to market just to launch without permissions or compliance with regulatory and deal with the consequences later, firstly?

And then secondly, as it relates to the FedNow project, I guess the question is, why kind of start and build a new network, instead of just taking advantage of a clearinghouse type structure, etcetera? Thank you.

BRAINARD: So--let's see. With regard to the--can you reframe the first question?

QUESTION: Yes, sorry. Desperate questions. The first is just--like, what are the tools that the Fed and other regulators can put in place to coordinate, particularly when many technology--

BRAINARD: Across--

QUESTION: --companies are happy to launch without--without approvals, etcetera, and just deal with the consequences later?

BRAINARD: Got it. So--and so, within borders, essentially, when activities have not sought particular licenses, but actually fall within the definitions of certain financial activities that are covered by financial regulations, they will get scoped in by the oversight of the relevant authorities. And that's what the discussions over the past several years, actually, starting with cryptocurrencies, have been about at places like the CFTC and the SEC.

So, when new activities arise, they may well fall under existing regulatory parameters, according to the legal provisions, whether or not, the---the innovators believe that or designed it in the first place.

The thing that I think is really important, though, for that question and the previous question, is just the reason the financial system has these safeguards that have been built up over decades is because there have been so many instances, historically, where financial panics have fundamentally disrupted economies, and where consumer's households and businesses, have found that their financial holdings were not as safe as they had anticipated. And that is why we have these very important safeguards in place.

With regard to FedNow, there are a few reasons. First of all, the Fed is the only entity that actually can facilitate real-time settlement between the accounts of banks, directly. The private sector entity, by necessity, is a private ledger that is a joint account structure.

And so, if we don't build that capacity, it simply won't exist. And for purposes of resilience and for purposes of kind of future proofing real-time payments, it's a very important function to build.

Secondly, the Federal Reserve connects to 10,000 institutions, depositories, and other institutions around the country. The clearinghouse and its various payment systems, often sits alongside the Fed, and offers payment solutions in the ACH and electronic funds transfers. So, this would be the norm rather than a departure.

But it's only the Fed that tends to make connections to the 10,000 institutions that facilitate payments. And we have the existing network and customer service built out, which is a lot of work to go that last mile. So, we're really building on existing infrastructure, in many respects.

POSEN: Thank you. Next, second one in the back if you'd go to the standing mic, please.

Thank you.

QUESTION: Dion Rabouin from Axios. My question is just on the, I guess, the state of things, or where we are at the moment. I just came from a presentation with David Marcus from Libra, and he seems to be putting forth the notion they're ready to go, kick start things as soon as they can kind of get the approval. So, I'm curious where's the Fed with an example of, or with an actual, presentable, U.S. digital currency.

I've heard from some members of the Swedish Central Bank that they are five years away. Chinese central bank says they've got something to produce by November. So, I'm just curious where--where do you think we are with regard to actually having a Fed produced, or Fed backed, digital currency. And where do you see the rest of the world?

BRAINARD: Yeah, so the two jurisdictions that you mentioned, and I think you'll get to hear from one of them on this panel, part of what is present in their payment system is a--there has been a very rapid migration away from cash--to digital payments.

And actual thing you might think is--what's actually new when (INAUDIBLE) technological trends already. And we have already e-money at this debate about the cashless economy already 20 years ago. And I would like to make some arguments that this time is different for the following reasons.

One is that what money now is much more associated with digital platform. So, you're part of an ecosystem, a digital ecosystem where you do--part of your life is your digital life. Essentially, you live on this platform. And this gives this platform some data (INAUDIBLE) they can use for other purposes as well. That's very different from previous e-monies where it actually it was not part of this digital platform where the data played this crucial role. The other important point is that everything is on the smartphone. So, it's easy to carry around. It's with tokens. You can pay--make tokens. And put this together--makes this much more speedier world. So, the payments will occur in real time. People demand to pay in real time. They can't wait for two days for some payments to be happening. And that means much less can be netted out within the bank. So, you have to have much, much less netting. So, you have much more cost settlement going on. And when there's a crisis, of course, the crisis will be much faster. There will be no weekend or anything to deal with that.

The other thing which will happen is the Internet of things. There will be payments from machine to machine, not only from person to person. There will be smart contracts and (INAUDIBLE). So, a lot of contingent payments whenever something happens. There will be contingent payments that will be a lot of volume coming from smart contracts' executions.

And finally, of course, you have tokens instead of account based systems. So, all of these things might impact money, and we would like to highlight some of the aspects which money might be impacted. So, the first thing I would like to--so, the currency competition will change, and it will change in one way that it leads to some unbundling to the three roles of money.

So, typically, we have this unit of account (INAUDIBLE) store value, medium of exchange. And (INAUDIBLE) already postulated in the 70s that we should actually have some currency competition because this actually keeps the governments in check not to print too much money. But, the currency competition didn't work so fiercely, in particular with respect to private aspects because whenever you hold some money, you get the bundle of services. You don't get just one store value service or unit of account or some medium exchange service. That actually limits competition among the currencies.

But, in the future you can hold 37 currencies in your wallet or your smartphone. You can switch from one currency to another one very easily. You might prefer a particular currency to make payments on that platform or a particular currency to--has a store of value. So, you can easily switch around. So, you can see much more fierce competition among the currencies because you have this unbundling of the three roles of currency.

Of course, it's not new. We have already convertibility between gold and silver, historically, led to some unbundling where you still have a (INAUDIBLE) for payments as a medium of exchange and gold much more as a store of value and for larger transactions. So, the (INAUDIBLE) is essentially also a form of unbundling. But, more generally, it will be the case that switching costs from one currency to another currency is going down. This reduces network externalities. And that actually then leads to much lower forms of--much fiercer competition because you have this unbundling.

And one nice analogy I think is--what often people say that money is--we coordinate on a particular money is like language. We also coordinate on a particular language. So, we use certain sounds and communicate with certain sounds. And we coordinate on these languages. And it's very hard to switch from one language to the next one to--but, once we have the speech translation software, we'll--you know, Skype or whatever software is it can translate immediately what we're saying in another language.

And people will provide--or institutions will provide some currencies which are very well suited for this particular platform. You cannot use the smart contracts otherwise.

And there will be--in general, there will be institutions providing currencies, offering different features with the money attached to it. So, there will be a rebundling with other features. And there will be this--what I call this money product differentiation. So, there will be some monies which are very good in providing price transparency in this particular platform. Others will be--more currencies which have more privacy protection.

So, Apple Pay is actually already going this way. So, if you want to have particular privacy--if you're very concerned about privacy, you might choose a certain currency. If you're not concerned about private but much more about how many points you get or miles you get or other things, then actually use a different currency. Or that will be competition among these various things. And, of course, this differentiation is designed to reduce competition among the currencies.

And to a large extent, the private sector will have an incentive to make essentially each ecosystem more closed, to make it less interoperable among the systems in order to get some rents from using this currency. And this will lead to, then, some digital currency areas. And as it came up earlier, there is also digital dollarization in a sense that there will be some vulnerable country. So, like with additional dollarization that suddenly the country loses its own currency and people suddenly start using dollars or whatever the leading currency is, the same can also happen in a digital space.

And the question is which countries are most vulnerable to digital dollarization? And this probably--like for dollarizations--will be small countries. But, it will also be countries which are relatively open, which don't have their own social media platforms where the citizens already rely on a social media platform for other countries. And these countries are much more vulnerable to digital dollarization. But, because of the medium exchange role it serves in this platform, it might become a very attractive currency to take over other countries because of the medium of exchange aspects to it.

And finally, the third implications for the international monetary system is the digital synthetic world currency (INAUDIBLE) they are talking about, you know--some people were arguing, "Oh, there might be some (INAUDIBLE) on the base of digital currency." And the reason for that is whenever there's a crisis and there's flight to safety, it leads actually to flight to safety across borders, and that's further destabilizing because everybody holds, let's say, the U.S. dollar or dollar assets as a safe asset. If you have a safe asset, which is more symmetrically distributed for across the globe, a truly global safe asset, you will not have the cross border flight to safety flows. That's much more centered around banks, and banks have access to the customers directly, all the lending, deposit taking, payments--everything is going around the bank side. And the bank has a lot of information about the customers and can make use of this information, whether they give a loan or don't give a loan and so forth.

The payment centric world is what we see already in China where the payment platform is at the center, and the information is with this payment platform provider. And the bank is essentially just feeding information--just feeding funds to the payment platform. But, all the information--information rent is with the payment platform. And then, the question is what is the optimal way of bundling it? Of course, the regulatory framework will play a major role which direction it goes, and probably some countries will go more the bank centric way and other countries will go more the payment centric way.

Now, let me come back to the currency competition, in particular, the competition between private and public money, so between the sovereign, its own money, and the public. And the question essentially becomes, very dramatically phrased, is Facebook doing the monetary policy to manage our macroeconomy? Is Facebook our new central bank is Libra is taking over?

And so, the question then is, you know, what makes--what's the advantage of a public money versus private money? But, what--what really makes public money special--there are three arguments, going back to the three roles of money. One is the store of value focus, and that's because, in order to defend a currency--how do you defend a currency if there's an attack? You have to tax back, and you have the taxing authority. So, let me sum up to the main points of the paper. The main points of the paper is that the world is changing in particular ways. We have e-money before. But, what's really the new aspects which drive things are the digital platforms and the digital ecosystems where a lot of our transactions will move to retail is moving with Amazon and many, many other things will be executed at digital platforms other than physically going to a retail store. And for that, digital money is way more useful than cash is.

The smartphone is a second element and token based accounts. These are the three elements which really make this very different from the earlier movements. And what we will see is essentially some specialization in currencies where the unbundle the three roles--the traditional three roles of money. And this unbundling itself enhances currency competition. So--because unbundling leads to competition, each of the functions of the money--so you can have much more currency competition in this dimension.

But, there will be some rebundling, which reduces currency competition. The first one is to make sure--and this is not a feature of the current system--that people who are underbanked or unbanked don't get ripped off as much as they do right now with the ATM fees and other things. That seems pretty easy, and it's low hanging fruit in the U.S. But, your--Sweden doesn't have that. It's a much more efficient system. That seems like a pressing need to fix that in the near term.

The other one is the data that is being used. It should be the case that the people are going to use their data pay you for using that data. And the more that you can construct a system where there's some regulation around that, the better off you'll be. The one thing you probably want to make clear when you're doing this--and this goes back to my last point--is this is not an attempt to get deeply negative nominal rates. You're not trying to get to a point you can do that. That would be--it would destabilize the financial system in the transition.

WOLF: Yes, your turn.

SHIN: Just--I mean, just a following up on--on Stefan's six points--I think his fifth one, which was on the importance of a system of digital IT, I think this really, really crucial. I think--I've described how, in many countries, retail payments using technology is incredibly seamless and--and very easy. But, cross border payment still is the bottleneck. And I think this is where we have a lot more work to do. Partly, the impediments are technological. And this is where the limits of the account based money come in because typically, if you try and make a cross border payment using account based money, you have to go through several intermediaries. And the reason is you need an intermediary where both the receiver and the sender have to have deposits so that you can transfer the--the deposits from the payer to the--to the receiver.

But, more important, they know your customer--know your customer checks where--they can be very onerous. They can be very time consuming. And, you know, we come across these figures all the time. The World Bank has done a study where, if you make a $200 payment, you're spending $14 just as a fee typically. I think this is one area where, from a financial inclusion perspective, we--we really need to make progress. I think having a digital ID system where--which allows the payment systems across countries to talk to each other is going to be a very, very important first step. As for that--

POTTER: (INAUDIBLE)

SHIN: No, not a--not a global ID, but at least having the--the--opening up the possibility where the--where payment systems of two different jurisdictions can actually make the (INAUDIBLE) process much more seamless. And--and I think if we can address this issue, many of the--the arguments one hears for why stable coins--global stable coins are going to be--are, in fact, necessary, are, in fact, going to improve customer experience, I think, will be, you know, much less strong.

But, this is one area where we have to acknowledge, as policymakers, that the progress has been least satisfactory.

INGVES: I'll add a couple things to do. And--and where it gets hard when we're talking about where to draw the line between--between the central bank and--and--and the private sector is we are so accustomed to having central banks. So, what you really need to think through is what would the system look without a central bank completely? And that takes you back to the 1800s, in the U.S., for example, and all the issues people worked through back in--back in those days. And I'm not talking about using somebody else's currency, somebody else's central bank. I'm talking about the intellectual bank when you think through no central bank at all, none, anywhere--anywhere in the world and what you--what you get.

And then, usually, people would come up with the conclusion that we need a central bank. So then, you would reinvent the central bank.

POTTER: Regulation, you definitely need.

INGVES: Yeah.

WOLF: Sorry. What was that?

POTTER: Regulation (INAUDIBLE).

INGVES: One--one issue that--

WOLF: --You couldn't--without a central bank, you couldn't have our financial system. So, the--you'd really be starting from scratch--

INGVES: --But, let me add one issue that--referring to Hume's reflection, when it comes to cross border payments and why this is a relevant issue as of--as of today. We're presently talking to the ECB about using their real time low value gross settlement system that runs 24/7 for euros. But, starting in 2021, if we can come to an agreement with the ECB, we can use the system for Swedish kroner.

And what that means that we have two currencies running real time. You probably don't have to be Einstein's brother to fix--figure out how to do the switch. And given that we're actually talking about the same computer system and the same servers--and that means that if we can solve that in harmony among--within the central bank community, then I just can't see what the value added of Libra would be in that environment. But, anyway, that's my view. It's a competitive business.

WOLF: It's very important for you that this be closed soon because we started very, very late.

(LAUGHTER)

So--and I was proposing to allow them to talk a little bit longer. But, if you want to close it, I will do so.

POSEN: Sorry for the--sorry for the logistical interruption. Point one, if people are content to let the geniuses talk longer, I think you will get value out of it.

(LAUGHTER)

I will put a hard deadline at 5:45 because we want people to have a chance to eat and drink. Second, I thank Martin for stepping in. I apologize for not having made the seamless transition to Martin. I was coughing, and I didn't want to distract. So, I stepped out. Third, whenever this is done, Markus gets the last word.

(LAUGHTER)

WOLF: You have described perfectly how we intend to proceed. So, it's what we're going to do. At this stage, I have many, many further questions, huge number. But, I--in the next say, ten, 15 minutes, let's have some questions. And then, we'll allow Markus--I'm going allow each of them to have another 30 seconds or so to summarize the single most important thing you should take away from what they said, and then, we'll have Markus. So, any questions? Please--the same rules apply. Say who you are and stand up. You will be (INAUDIBLE) will be the next one.

QUESTION: Thank you. This has been a fantastic panel. Thank you very much. I've learned a lot. So, I raised this question to--oh, sorry. I'm (INAUDIBLE) from the IMF. So, I've asked this question to Markus earlier at lunchtime. So, I'm going to ask the same question to the other panelists. So, in a way, I very much agree with Markus that the unit of account is probably the most important function of money, and, of course, that's what central banks care most about.

So, why do you think that Libra, as it's proposed, has a different unit of account? Might it have been much easier if they had proposed a Libra that's backed only to the U.S. dollar? So, what is the reason? So, do we have to worry about that platform monies, even if it's not Libra--similar concepts might survive. Why do they have an incentive to have a different unit of account? Thank you.

WOLF: The way I'm going to do this--my normal way--we're not going to--you're not going to answer these questions. They're going to take three--two or three. Then, I will decide which of them are going to be asked and in which order.

(LAUGHTER)

This is--this is not a democracy.

(LAUGHTER)

Patrick, yes please.

QUESTION: (INAUDIBLE) Peterson Institute. My question about Libra really--and the excitement that this has generated--so, what--why do we think Libra is--you know, could--could be big very quickly? It's because, I suppose--because they have a large number of affiliates at the moment, you know, members, who trust the brand, and it's credible that this big company can work out (INAUDIBLE) credible payments technology. So, that explains why they might get a huge portion of the retail payment system.

But, it's not clear to me why this should attract in any short term scale a large portion of the wholesale payment system or any large scale at all of the store of value and why they should be able to compete with, you know, BlackRock, Vanguard, et cetera, et cetera. Am I completely wrong about that? I'm not saying that in 50 years' time it'll be all big tech companies. But, this particular (INAUDIBLE) seems smaller than the amount of reaction that we're getting from--about it.

WOLF: (OFF-MIC)

QUESTION: Thank you. I'm with Bloomberg News. Can I ask for your broad take on China's push to credits on digital currency, the central bank digital currency? The design of it certainly differs a lot from what it--what we talked about today, the digital currency for general purpose. What's your view on their approach, and what would be the implication on either Alipay or WeChat or other monetary authorities overseas trying to look at a similar topic? Thank you.

WOLF: So, there are two questions--and we can bring them together--about Libra. What on earth where they thinking, I think, is the first one, and why. I'd review, but I'm not a panelist. And surely there are inherent limits on what it can achieve, particularly beyond the retail system, which I think is a very important point about these platforms. And in Facebook case, it's not a trusted transaction platform anyway. So, it would seem to sort of make sense for Amazon because it is a trusted transactions platform. My own humble view--and I'm on the record--is that anyone who trusts Facebook for anything is a deluded fool.

(LAUGHTER)

But, the--anyway, anyone wants to talk specifically about the Libra idea because it's obviously a big issue. Hyun, are you prepared to say something about it?

SHIN: Well, to Patrick's question, I alluded earlier to the--to the limits of a cash in advance system for--for wholesale payments. If you have to top up your--your wallet before you make the payment and you cannot be overdrawn, given the kind of sums we are talking about in the wholesale payment system where you are actually paying the annual GDP in one week, it's not going to be, you know, very--in an efficient way to run the wholesale payment system.

On the store of value, it's also very interesting just to look at the magnitude for--for Alipay and WeChat pay as well because although they're very important players in the payment system, if you look at their balances, including the money market funds, if you add up the whole of the assets of the--of the payment float together with the money market fund, we only get to about two percent of the total deposits in the banking system in China.

So, it is a very, very small part of--of the overall financial assets. So, I think we have to, you know, keep these things in perspective. I think the--the interest that Libra has generated--I think it's--it goes back to what I'm referring to earlier, which is the idea that you can use the--the installed network base and then exploit that in the payment--in the provision of payment services and the possibility that you could get a walled garden, which is separate from the public backbone. And I think that's--I think the--I think some of the background to--to the misgivings that some people express.

WOLF: (INAUDIBLE) do you want to add anything on Libra?

POTTER: So, I think it's pretty obvious why they wanted a basket given the 2.7 billion people on--all located in this country. On the other hand, it'd be much easier to tell people it's backed by reserves held at the Federal Reserve. That would make everyone realize it was actually stable in value. It gets very hard to explain to people, when it's a basket, that it's stable. But, you--you don't know whether it's really stable. People would do a lot of transactions in--in dollars. That shows you that the politics of this are quite difficult.

Private actors aren't necessarily perfect at trying to deal with this. In terms of China, I don't know what the details are there. I will say that (INAUDIBLE) is an interesting entity there where they use some of this data. And they expend credit in a very quick way without ever having met people. They do use a lot of data to extend that credit, and it's not obvious in other countries we'd feel so happy with that. It's a very interesting way.

And just to go back to Martin's point, we shouldn't knock Facebook too much here. There could be tremendous value. It might not be measured in GDP. But, there could be some value here of how to connect people that we are missing. And I--I think you were trying to indicate that in the paper you wrote, that these platforms have told us quite a bit about what--what people value. It might not be measured in GDP. But, it could be something that has a lot of social value.

WOLF: (INAUDIBLE) point very quickly. I think this cross border aspect of Libra is, if it works, the core unique selling point, and it's a big deal. That comes out (INAUDIBLE) because cross border payments is an unspeakable mess, particularly for small transactors.

The second point is I did see the (INAUDIBLE) in some length in March talk about this. And they very much underlined what Hyun said, that really and truly, if you looked at what the big payment platforms do in monetary terms in China and even in payments, they're not doing all the corporate payments and all the rest of it. It's very much smaller than the numbers sometimes suggest.

Finally, Stefan, do you have anything to say on the PBOC (PH)?

INGVES: Well, it's--I mean, it's too early to tell. I know I certainly don't know what they're going to come up with and what they're going to do. But, there's one--one aspect to all of this, which is, again, repeating there's nothing new under the sun. My understanding is that for these new systems, they're now imposing a 100 percent reserve requirement. And that's exactly the conversation that we had in the late 1800s in my country, when the banks were issuing physical money and the central bank was issuing physical central bank money.

And then, there was also a very harsh reserve requirement imposed on the banks, and that ensured that you had an exchange rate one to one between central bank and private bank money. And without that, the system simply would not--would not have worked. And this is why I think they have come up with this conclusion. And--and that's the way it's going to be run presently because that's where you really have to decide whether you want to have a--a sort of (INAUDIBLE) or an exchange rate, which is easy to understand, one to one, in the system.

And if that goes out the window, then everybody will revert--revert back to central bank money in one form or the other.

WOLF: We're going to take one or possibly two more questions if they're really quick. So, this is your first--please say who you are and very, very quick question.

QUESTION: (INAUDIBLE) from East High (PH) Media Group. Very quickly--if we think private investors or state (INAUDIBLE) money like Libra is very dangerous, should we have a global central banking issued kind of (INAUDIBLE) issued kind of ESDR? It will be safer, or will ESDR dominate the global monetary system if the SDR failed to do that? And very quickly, for Hyun, you have--

WOLF: --I'm sorry. We're going to have to do one question--

QUESTION: --Oh, thank you.

WOLF: I'm sorry because I'm going to be killed if I let it go on.

QUESTION: It's okay.

WOLF: (INAUDIBLE) and that'll be the last one. Really sorry. But, you (INAUDIBLE).

QUESTION: Very simple--a very simple question. Six years ago, American Express introduced a credit card. So, it was substituting cash. It was substituting checks. It was a way to provide credit, and it provided massive information (INAUDIBLE) credit card and nothing changed. So, what is different this time.

WOLF: Okay. Who wants to talk about central bank (INAUDIBLE) and ESDR. Could it do substantially better than the original SDR has in being a successful reserve asset, in this case (INAUDIBLE) to successful money? Simon, you're shaking your head. So (OFF-MIC).

POTTER: The dollar works really well, and the network effects are massive. And you're not going to get people to coordinate in any real time on this. There are issues to how dominant the dollar is. That's why (INAUDIBLE) gave the speech he gave at Jackson Hole. But, he kept on saying, you've got to play the cards you have. And the notion that this is going to change over the next five years--it's not going to happen. The dollar is actually growing in importance.

And the fact--we talked a lot about Facebook Libra. If you look over the last few weeks, I don't think people's view of the success of that has gone up. I think it's gone close to zero.

WOLF: Hyun and Stefan, last--Hyun, it's essentially asking the question, is it really different this time? And in fact, Markus started this with his discussion of--the money debate was--what--20 years ago? I can't remember the exact figures. So, we've had credit cards. We've had payment cards. It hasn't really changed anything. Are we getting much too excited about what a change of technology when it really is not going to change the core architecture? Markus is putting forward the argument that his coauthors--that it really could change the core architecture. So, from your perceptions, you two, what do you think, very quickly? Is it--how different is it this time?

SHIN: I think the short answer is it remains to be seen.

(LAUGHTER)

Because it--I think--it's the only answer because I think it's too early to tell. There is a lot of excitement about the technology. But, take even the simple example of decentralized consensus and distributed ledger technology. That is--so, the technology and the cryptographic way of keeping track of who pays who has been advanced. But, it remains to be seen how widely that's going to be adopted and--and will make an impact.

And the initial indications are that it is a very exciting idea. It goes back to some of the roots of monetary economics, that we have a huge ledger that says who pay who and we can keep tabs rather than having pieces of paper or gold coins. But--and there's no doubt that technology has enabled us to realize some of these theoretical ideas in practice.

However, the returns that we've seen so far have been rather meager. And we'll need to see how far the technology is going to drive the function. I think this is--I would go back to my very first point. The technology is an enabler. It's not the end.

WOLF: And very briefly.

INGVES: If central banks adapt and start using new technologies themselves, then central banks will continue to be around for a long, long time to come. Had we stuck to 45 pound copper coins from the 1600s to today, we probably would not have existed.

(LAUGHTER)

WOLF: That's a nice answer. So, Markus--and a few minutes of reaction to what you've heard. But, really make it really brief.

BRUNNERMEIER: Let me first thank all of you for a great panel and also to the audience for being here until the end. Let me make a few comments, which I collected, to these different views. I think one thing which is striking that the age old issues resurface. And I agree--and it's an exciting time that you can restudy, essentially, old monetary theory.

But, I think there is one difference, and Simon pointed to it as well. I think it's connection to platforms and the data connection. I think it's way more pronounced this time, and I think that's the new element, combined with the token, which really makes this evolution, I think, different. It's also getting in terms of speed--whenever there's a financial crisis, too much, much faster development.

The other difference I see is that the danger of dollarization or digital dollarization is probably much more pronounced compared to credit cards. I don't see that, you know--a credit card is still in your national currency. It's not--I don't see that suddenly a foreign denominated credit card is taking over this country.

I don't think it's an issue for the U.S. because the dollar is very dominant and all this. But, for smaller countries, very open countries, that's, I think, a large--larger issue. With regard to retail transactions, I agree the retail is small. But, it might be the most lucrative way. So, the spreads, you know, you can do on the retail side, you can probably make a lot of money. That's probably what--not (INAUDIBLE) Facebook and others are looking at so you can have a lot of deposits. And going back to the Starbucks example, they don't get any interest on this money they are lending to Starbucks. And that's very lucrative, and Facebook probably sees there will be perhaps a billion dollars or some billion dollars you can borrow for free in a high interest environment, a high inflation environment. That's very, very lucrative. You won't get this from professional investors because a lot of those financial transactions might be (INAUDIBLE) to a large extent (INAUDIBLE) shows up in this--in these wholesale transactions.

So, that's why I wouldn't downplay the retail side too much. I agree the financial inclusion is the big component. I think that's one--I don't see it with Libra (INAUDIBLE) doing a huge financial inclusion. But, I think that should be the argument we should put forward.

I see a big disagreement on the panel with regard to CBDC. I think Stefan is very in favor of it, and that's--Sweden is going forward with it. Simon is very against it or that's--

(LAUGHTER)

POTTER: --In some sizes (INAUDIBLE)--

BRUNNERMEIER: --In small size, it's okay. So, there is a big debate still ongoing. I don't think we ever solved that. And finally, I would like to come back--what Martin mentioned in the beginning. It might be a better way, the whole evolution (INAUDIBLE) might actually lead to a much more efficient system, especially more financial inclusions. But, we don't know yet how it will look like. But, even transition is actually very difficult, very risky, and it might take a century and (INAUDIBLE) financial crisis and a great depression to get it--get there. So, it might be very risky.

So, coming back to (INAUDIBLE) presentation, why should the U.S. do it? Why should we risk the whole global financial system with the dollar? Let's just do it with a small country and hope that Stefan is offering Sweden to be the experimenter.

(LAUGHTER)

And I think (INAUDIBLE) we should offer some backup (INAUDIBLE) policy to what Sweden--because we all learn--the whole world will learn from the Swedish experiment or perhaps Israel or some other country, which is very much (INAUDIBLE) driven can move ahead. And I--I hope that, for human beings and for the innovation itself, that some countries move ahead with some guarantees from other countries to do that. And we will see how these things will play out.

WOLF: Okay. I'm getting queued. But, I'd just like to end up with--I think somebody mentioned (INAUDIBLE) view on economic processes and the crisis when it happens is quicker than you ever imagined. My memory now (INAUDIBLE) this about 20 years ago. And I think it was Bill Gates. But, it might have been somebody else made essentially the same point about technology. This was the beginning of the dotcom bubble and all the rest of it.

And the argument was essentially fundamentally new technologies change the world much more slowly than most people originally expect. But, in the end, they change it completely. And I have a pretty strong suspicion that, in this case--though, I wish it weren't the case or, in some ways, I don't--that this is going to be an example, that this is the case. So, it won't be a completely different financial world five years from now, but 20 years from now, I suspect it will be. And so, we should prepare for that. I think it's been a wonderful panel. And now, I'm going to lead Adam to conclude it.

(APPLAUSE)

urn:contentItem:5D4G-FBN1-DY2S-N3R8-00000-00Peter Thiel In 'Zero To One': How To Develop The Developed World2014-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisWeekend Edition Saturday12:00 AM ESTWallace LanghamJesse EisenbergPeter ThielPeter Thiel In 'Zero To One': How To Develop The Developed World

WADE GOODWYN: You might remember this scene from the movie "The Social Network."

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "THE SOCIAL NETWORK")

WALLACE LANGHAM: (As Peter Thiel) You must be Mark.

JESSE EISENBERG: (As Mark Zuckerberg) Hi.

WALLACE LANGHAM: (As Peter Thiel) We took a look at everything and congratulations, we're going to start you off with a $500,000 investment. Maurice is going to talk to you about...

WADE GOODWYN: That guy you just heard offering $500,000 to a young Mark Zuckerberg - that's Peter Thiel. Well, not really. It's an actor playing Peter Thiel. Thiel was Facebook's first outside investor. He also co-founded PayPal and Palantir Technologies. And through his venture capital firm Founders Fund, he's invested in a number of big-tech companies. He's written a book with Blake Masters. It's called "Zero To One: Notes On Startups, Or How To Build The Future." Welcome, Peter.

PETER THIEL: Thanks for having me on the show.

WADE GOODWYN: It's our pleasure. Your first piece of advice seemed to me to be your most important, and that is that Facebook and Microsoft and Google have already been created. So what these guys did in creating those success stories is not your roadmap. Your roadmap will be your roadmap.

PETER THIEL: Yes. I believe that every moment in the history of business only happens once. And so the next Bill Gates will not be building an operating system company. The next Larry Page will not be building a search engine. The next Mark Zuckerberg won't be building a social network. And so if you're trying to copy these guys, in some sense you're not really learning from them. And one of the challenges is teaching entrepreneurship or writing about it is that there's no cookie-cutter formula that you can follow.

WADE GOODWYN: So if you can't really give them a roadmap, and you say to them, you know, in order to be a success, you have to be original. How do you help students or would-be entrepreneurs?

PETER THIEL: There is still a surprising amount one can say. There's sort of an interview question I like to ask people which is tell me something that is true that very few people agree with you on. The business version of this question is what great business is nobody building? And these questions turn out to be quite hard to answer for two somewhat different reasons. One of them is it's always hard to come up with new truths that people have not yet understood. Secondly, it also requires a bit of courage because you often have to go against social convention in pursuing certain lines of business. People discourage you from doing things that are strange and new.

WADE GOODWYN: I think it's a capitalist truism that competition breeds efficiency and innovation. But you believe monopolies are actually better. Talk about that.

PETER THIEL: Well, I think people always say that capitalism and competition are synonyms. But I think they're really antonyms. If we look at the restaurant industry, it's a very competitive industry. But it's very, very hard to make money opening a restaurant because all the profits are competed away, whereas a company like Google has not had any real competition in search since 2002 when it definitively distanced itself from Yahoo and Microsoft, and is therefore a very profitable business. You can debate how much monopoly should be regulated or when is it a good monopoly that's inventing something new and is dynamic? When it is a bad monopoly that becomes more like a rent collector? But I do think the great fortunes are always made in these monopoly-like businesses.

WADE GOODWYN: Your book is entitled "Zero To One." What does that mean?

PETER THIEL: The basic idea is if you sort of think about innovations where there's someone who builds a first airplane or first home computer or first smartphone that works like the Apple iPhone, these are what I call zero to one innovations. And I think technology involves intensive, vertical, zero to one progress. Globalization involves horizontal, copying, one to end progress. And we'll need both of these in the 21st century. China is sort of the epitome of globalization. What China does is copy things that work. And it has a very straightforward 20-year plan which is to make itself look more like the U.S. and Western Europe. For the developed world - Japan, Western Europe, the United States - progress is a much trickier thing in 21st-century because to take our civilization to the next level, we need to actually do new things. And so I think the question of how do we develop the developed world is a question that's not often asked but is worth for us to look about a lot more.

WADE GOODWYN: You've been publicly skeptical of the value of college. What's not happening there you think should be?

PETER THIEL: Well, if I had to do it over again, I probably would still go to college, but I would think a lot harder about why I went. I think we have often let education become a substitute for thinking about the future. And it's become much more problematic for the younger generation which is amassing enormous amount of student debt. I believe that there is no one-size-fits-all trajectory, and that there is something a little bit unhealthy about the sort of society that says you go to Yale or you go to jail. We need to create a much more diverse array of alternatives. I think the sort of narrowly-tracked system we have is working less and less well.

WADE GOODWYN: Are you optimistic or pessimistic about this country's technological future?

PETER THIEL: Well, I've articulated the view that there has been a lot of progress in the world of bits and not so much in the world of atoms. So there's been a lot of progress in computers, not as much in some other areas such as say energy or transportation or even biomedical. And so the hope is that we can re-accelerate progress so that technology's not just synonymous with computers. I never like to frame things, however, in terms of extreme optimism or extreme pessimism because they both end up being reasons not to do anything. If you're extremely optimistic, then the future will take care of itself. If you're extremely pessimistic, then there's nothing they can do. And so they both are mindsets that I think lead to inaction. And so I think the healthier mindset is always somewhere in between - to say that there's some good things and some bad things, and we have to figure out what are the meaningful things we can do in our time.

WADE GOODWYN: Peter Thiel is the author of "Zero To One." Peter, good talking to you.

PETER THIEL: Thanks for having me.
