urn:contentItem:5RB1-G7R1-DXY4-X3SG-00000-00Peter Thiel Is a Bitcoin Believer: DealBook Briefing2018-01-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisBUSINESSdealbookPeter Thiel Is a Bitcoin Believer: DealBook Briefing

The value of the digital currency jumped this afternoon after Mr. Thiel’s Founders Fund venture firm emerged as an investor.

Good Tuesday and happy new year!

Bitcoin’s value jumped as Peter Thiel’s venture firm emerged as an investor in the currency.

Regulatory concerns sink Ant Financial’s purchase of MoneyGram.

The Nasdaq Composite closed above 7,000 for the first time.

Breakingviews thinks 2018 will be a frothy, frustrating year.

The analyst Gene Munster thinks Amazon should make a big leap into brick-and-mortar retail.

Want this in your own email inbox? Here’s the sign-up.

Peter Thiel is betting big on Bitcoin.

The value of the digital currency leapt about $1,000 this afternoon. Why? Turns out that the venture capitalist and his firm are believers.

From Rob Copeland of the WSJ:

Founders Fund, the venture-capital firm co-founded by Peter Thiel, has amassed hundreds of millions of dollars of the volatile cryptocurrency, people familiar with the matter said. The bet has been spread across several of the firm’s most recent funds, the people said, including one that began investing in mid-2017 and made bitcoin one of its first investments.

As of this writing, Bitcoin is valued at about $14,655.

Why buy Bitcoin? Founders Fund is, after all, a venture firm rather than a hedge fund. But the firm apparently believes that start-up valuations currently are sky-high, while digital currencies will continue to climb in worth.

Has Founders Fund made money? The WSJ reports, citing its unnamed sources, that the firm bought about $15 million in Bitcoin and that its stake is now worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

— Michael J. de la Merced

So much for Jack Ma’s charm offensive.

So much for Jack Ma’s charm offensive.

United States officials have effectively killed Ant Financial’s $1.2 billion bid to buy MoneyGram.

Ant Financial, the electronic payments company controlled by Mr. Ma, became the latest Chinese firm to have its acquisition of an American company fall apart because it was unable to secure approval from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or Cfius.

The deal failed despite a charm offensive by Jack Ma, the Chinese internet. Shortly after President Trump won the 2016 election, Mr. Ma famously stood with the president-elect in Trump Tower in New York City and pledged that his e-commerce empire would help create one million American jobs.

The attempted purchase of MoneyGram was seen as a test of the Trump administration’s political and regulatory approach to China, and the deal’s failure could spell trouble for other Chinese companies considering major acquisitions.

The strong flow of Chinese money into the United States has prompted growing worries. Lawmakers from both parties have introduced legislation calling for greater scrutiny of Chinese investments in the United States. They are pushing for a significant expansion of Cfius, a multiagency panel that reviews foreign deals for potential threats to national security.

Of the deal, Richard Beales of Breakingviews writes:

“It would have been seen as something of a watershed for a successful upstart from the People’s Republic to get its hands on a piece of Uncle Sam’s payments infrastructure.

“For Trump and China critics in his administration, that may have been the wrong message, especially when a similar deal in the other direction would surely come up against Beijing’s tight restrictions on foreign ownership in China’s financial system. Rather than opening the door – arguably the old American way of showing how things ought to be done – CFIUS this time kept it closed. If it’s a rebuke, it’s one that’s conveniently unlikely to provoke great resentment.”

MoneyGram’s shares are down 6.8 percent after the close.

Tech’s 2017 rally spilled over into the New Year

The Nasdaq Composite rose 1.5 percent Tuesday to close above 7,000 for the first time.

The gain was driven by Netflix, Facebook, Google-parent Alphabet and Apple, which jumped between 18 percent and 4.8 percent.

Tuesday’s rally follows a 28 percent gain for the Nasdaq last year. That beat the 25 percent gain for the Dow Jones industrial average and the 19 percent rise for the Standard & Poor’s 500 index.

So how stretched are valuations for the Nasdaq? As of Friday, the index was trading at 27.55 times the last 12 months of earnings, well above the S.&P. 500′s level of 18.27 times earnings, according to the WSJ’s Ben Eisen. But the Nasdaq’s current price-to-earnings ratio remains well below 72.2, which it hit in March 2000.

Extra Credit: Yes, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon.com drove the Nasdaq’s run to 7,000. But Riot Blockchain saw the biggest percentage gain between the Nasdaq’s first close above 6,000 in April to its close above 7,000 on Tuesday, writes the WSJ’s Chelsey Dulaney. Shares of Riot “surged more than 640 percent during that period, with the bulk of those gains coming after the company switched its focus to investing in blockchain technology October.”

Our thoughts exactly.

Shot: Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, won’t run for re-election, according to the NYT. That gives Mitt Romney — former presidential candidate, former Massachusetts governor,   former private equity mogul, current (and increasingly frequent)   Trump critic — a chance to run for the seat.

Chaser:

— Michael J. de la Merced

Expect a “frothy” and “frustrated” 2018.

Money is cheap, the global economy is gaining momentum and markets are at records. “Yet things look less reassuring close up,” writes Quentin Webb of Breakingviews.

“The populist anger that enabled Trump and Brexit is still simmering, fueled by inequality, disruption, immigration and the echo chambers of social media. An unpredictable America is no longer committed to advancing a rules-based, liberal world order. China is growing increasingly assertive under President Xi Jinping, while Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is flexing his muscles around the Gulf. The risk of a conflagration on the Korean Peninsula is all too real. Business is grappling with self-inflicted scandals and activist attacks, and a backlash is building against Big Tech’s overweening power.”

With that as the backdrop, here are a few of Breakingviews’ predictions for 2018:

In investing

“For the first time in years, rich-world bond issuance will outstrip buying by the Fed and friends,” and “bond vigilantes will rise from the dead.”

“Passive funds will, despite their name, dethrone a chief executive.”

In tech

“In tech, investors can consider a tasty new dish: SLAW, for Spotify, Lyft, Airbnb and WeWork, four prospective candidates for public life.”

Apple’s position as a privacy-sensitive hardware specialist will give it some shelter from mounting anger at Silicon Valley’s power and lack of accountability.

— Stephen Grocer

Dreaming of an Amazon-Target deal.

We’re just two days into 2018, and we already have a huge M.&A. prediction, courtesy of the analyst Gene Munster.

From his note yesterday:

Getting the timing on this is difficult, but seeing the value of the combination is easy. Amazon believes the future of retail is a mix of mostly online and some offline. Target is the ideal offline partner for Amazon for two reasons, shared demographic and manageable but comprehensive store count.

It’s a big, if logical, assumption given the ever-expanding empire that Amazon has been assembling — one that has put more and more industry incumbents on their back heels.

Target shares were up nearly 4 percent as of this afternoon.

Could Amazon afford Target?

Short answer: Yes.

Long answer: Yes, but it’d be pretty expensive. Target’s market capitalization as of Tuesday morning was nearly $37 billion. Amazon had about $24.3 billion in cash and short-term investments on its balance sheet as of Sept. 30, meaning that the company would have to borrow a hefty amount.

Assuming a 20 percent takeover premium, Target would be almost $40 billion.

Amazon could pay in stock as well as cash, but it hasn’t struck a big deal using stock since its takeover of Zappos in 2009. And stock remains an expensive form of currency, though that hasn’t stopped the likes of Disney from stock deals.

(Mr. Munster asserts that a deal is affordable because the cost of a Target acquisition is just 8 percent of Amazon’s market cap. Obviously, I think it’s a bit more complicated than that.)

The big caveat (other than price)

Obviously, it’s antitrust. Mr. Munster notes that a combined Amazon-Target would only have about a 13 percent share of the overall American retail market, compared to Walmart’s 23 percent.

But it’s hard to determine at the moment what the Trump administration’s yardstick for market concentration is:

AT&T and Time Warner say that their proposed deal is a vertical deal that falls within the bounds of acceptable deals. The Justice Department has sued to block that.

Disney and Fox have announced a deal that would inevitably lead to lots of layoffs. President Trump has praised that transaction as potentially “great for jobs.”

“As for antitrust, the Trump administration won’t do any favors for Jeff Bezos, but the market share numbers suggest the deal will be approved,” Mr. Munster writes. That’s a potentially big assumption.

— Michael J. de la Merced

Are Amazon and Salesforce moving away from Oracle?

Kevin McLaughlin of The Information reports that the two companies “are actively working to replace Oracle software running on critical business systems with open-source database software alternatives, and have made significant progress toward getting off Oracle entirely,” citing people familiar with the matter.

“A mass exodus from the Oracle database isn’t likely anytime soon. Yet losing Amazon and Salesforce as customers could pose major problems for Oracle, as it could provide a road map for other large companies that also are looking to cut costs by jettisoning Oracle database software in favor of open-source database alternatives.”

Oracle’s shares are down nearly 2 percent. They had been trading about 1 percent higher before the report.

— Stephen Grocer

Where are stocks heading in 2018?

The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 25 percent in 2017. Does that mean investors should turn bearish on stocks this year? The answer is no if history is any indicator, LPL Financial’s Ryan Detrick points out.

Also, is the first day of trading predictive of the stock market’s performance for the full year?

— Stephen Grocer

Remembering 2017, and looking ahead to 2018.

If you couldn’t recall last year’s highlights over the recent holidays, Andrew can remind you with his annual year-end column (the humor of which is his and his alone). A sample:

The seating chart is, of course, always a bit complicated. We had to keep Jeffrey Bezos of Amazon from the dais to prevent Mr. Trump’s Twitter war with him from interrupting the festivities. And we had heard that Mr. Bezos had a practical joke planned: He was going to tell Mr. Trump that he had chosen Mexico City as Amazon’s second headquarters.

But it’s a new year, and here are some important story lines we’ll be keeping our eyes on:

Now that the tax fight is over, the White House is turning to trade. Will Gary Cohn and Steven Mnuchin be able to tame President Trump’s hard-line tendencies?

Can Congress make progress on the many, many other issues it’s facing?

SoftBankdid   its Uber deal. Will the ride-hailing giant make further strides toward going public this year? (   Maybe not.) And what will Masa Son of SoftBank and his $100 billion Vision Fund get up to?

What other industries will Amazon disrupt this year? And   how much bigger can Mr. Bezos’s behemoth get?

North Korea is trying to drive a wedge between South Korea and the U.S. And it   seems to be working. How will Mr. Trump — and the global economy — respond?

Stevie Cohen is finding takers for his new hedge fund. But how much presence will he retain in the industry?

In the world of M. & A. fights, who will AT&T or the Justice Department prevail? Broadcom or Qualcomm? And will Disney and Fox get their deal done?

Businesses are opening their wallets.

And the Trump administration’s deregulatory push looks to be a reason for that — even if skeptics question whether rolling back government rules stimulates corporate growth.

Corporate leaders always cite “uncertainty” as a reason to hold back on capital expenditures or transformative acquisitions. And fewer than half of the respondents in the National Association of Manufacturers’ most recent survey said they faced an “unfavorable business climate.”

Yet some see a bigger phenomenon at work. This is what Mark Zandi of Moody’s Analytics told the NYT:

“The fundamental backdrop here is that this is a global synchronized expansion lifting everyone’s spirits, from Tokyo to New York.”

The tax flyaround

Corporate America’s great loophole scavenger hunt has begun. (NYT)

China has responded to the tax law by temporarily exempting foreign companies from taxes on their earnings in the country — but there’s a catch. (NYT)

Democrats in high-tax states are seeking ways to blunt some of the impact of the tax overhaul. (NYT)

The gig economy could get a boost. (NYT)

Betting on the dollar continuing to strengthen in 2018, thanks to the tax law. (WSJ)

The Murdoch family tensions behind the Disney deal.

It may have been a brief sales negotiation with Verizon that prompted Rupert Murdoch to consider selling pieces of 21st Century Fox. But the NYT reports that friction between the media mogul and his son James helped push the family toward the Disney transaction.

From the article by Brooks Barnes and Sydney Ember:

James Murdoch has privately grumbled about the control that his father still exerted at Fox and has chafed at some of the elements of Fox News’s coverage.

Rupert Murdoch was wary of how Hollywood was being reshaped by digital giants like Netflix, Apple and Amazon, and unsure his empire could compete.

Lachlan Murdoch, who is more conservative than his brother, has become the heir apparent at what would remain of Fox, but was initially uneasy about a sell-off.

What they gain: Beyond easing family tensions among the trio, the deal could make the Murdochs some of Disney’s biggest shareholders.

The mutual fund king bucking the low-fee wave.

Yes, Ron Baron has lowered fees on some of his smaller funds. But he’s unapologetic about charging roughly 54 percent more than the industry average.

Here’s what he told Landon Thomas Jr. of the NYT:

“Since inception, 98 percent of our funds have beaten their benchmark,” he said in an interview. “If you want the lowest fee, you should not invest with us.”

How he (and other mutual funds) do it: Chalk it up to a combination of looser oversight, the $10 trillion of investor money still dedicated to actively managed funds and a lack of investor awareness that high fees don’t necessarily pay for performance.

Can this go on?

One fund investor’s take in the NYT:

“I won’t say performance warrants the fees they charge,” said Barry Edelman, a Las Vegas retiree and a 20-year Baron shareholder. “But I appreciate how they differentiate themselves from the competition.”

Tragedy strikes Bridgewater.

Bruce Steinberg, an executive at the hedge fund, and his family were among the 12 killed when a single-engine plane crashed in Costa Rica on Sunday.

Ray Dalio of Bridgewater posted this to Facebook yesterday:

Also of note: Richard Cousins, the C.E.O. of Compass Group, the world’s biggest catering company, was one of six killed in a plane crash in Sydney on Sunday.

Hollywood organizes to fight sexual harassment.

What’s notable is that Time’s Up — formed by more than 300 women and including a legal-defense fund — isn’t focused only on the entertainment industry. It plans to offer help to janitors, nurses, hotel staff and other blue-collar workers.

Here’s what Shonda Rhimes, a backer of the initiative, told Cara Buckley of the NYT:

“If this group of women can’t fight for a model for other women who don’t have as much power and privilege, then who can?”

Who else is involved: The actresses America Ferrera, Eva Longoria and Reese Witherspoon; Donna Langley, the chairwoman of Universal Pictures; and roughly 295 other women in Hollywood.

What’s different: The Time’s Up Legal Defense Fund, which is backed by $13 million in donations and is overseen by Tina Tchen, a former chief of staff to Michelle Obama. It will help provide less-privileged women with lawyers to bring misconduct cases to court and protect them from blowback.

The misconduct flyaround

Take a peek behind the curtain at the monthly drug- and sex-fueled monthly parties attended by some of Silicon Valley’s most powerful men, in an excerpt from “Brotopia,” the forthcoming book by the Bloomberg anchor Emily Chang. (Vanity Fair)

The former Fox News anchor Gretchen Carlson, who was a Miss America, will take over as chairwoman of the pageant as it works through its harassment scandal. (NYT)

Business schools in the United States are hastily reshaping their curriculums with case studies on sexual harassment. (NYT)

Political partisans are starting to exploit the #MeToo movement. (NYT)

The former C.E.O. of SoFi, Mike Cagney, has approached potential investors about backing a fintech start-up. (Recode)

The longtime leader of the New York City Ballet, Peter Martins, has retired after accusations of sexual harassment and verbal and physical abuse. He denies wrongdoing. (NYT)

Read this story. (Lloyd Blankfein said so.)

Last week, the NYT reported on how the Metropolitan Transportation Authority ends up with some of the highest construction costs in the world. Some facts:

The Second Avenue subway cost $2.5 billion. Expanding Grand Central Terminal is now expected to cost $12 billion.

Construction companies inflate their projected costs by up to 50 percent for M.T.A. work. Labor unions have arranged for up to four times the necessary staffing on some projects.

Consultants have persuaded officials to spend heavily on design and management.

Here’s what Mr. Blankfein, Andrew’s choice as 2017’s best corporate tweeter, had to say:

(Mr. Blankfein has good reasons for pique over the tax law: Goldman Sachsis taking   a $5 billion charge in its fourth-quarter earnings tied to the changes.)

The Speed Read

Caterpillar faces a potential tax bill of $2 billion from the I.R.S., which says it has underpaid on profits from parts sales through its Swiss unit. (WSJ)

The new Salesforce Tower in San Francisco is the tallest office building west of the Mississippi, and a symbol of tech’s triumph in the city. (NYT)

Morgan Stanley is entering the robo-advice market, with an automated service that includes a choice of exchange-traded funds, mutual funds and seven themed portfolios. (FT)

Europe’s new “MiFID II” investment rules — on how research is paid for, how trades are documented and executed, and how brokers share information — come into force tomorrow. (Bloomberg)

Playboy Enterprises is considering shutting the print magazine to concentrate on licensing deals and brand partnerships. (WSJ)

Retail cannabis shops in California opened their doors on Monday, inaugurating what proponents say will become the world’s largest legal market for recreational marijuana. (NYT)

One of America’s biggest rehab companies built an empire. But after a patient died, its enemies — investors and rivals alike — struck hard. (NYT)

Andrew picked his favorite business (and business-adjacent) books of 2017, including “The Spider Network” by David Enrich, “Reset” by Ellen Pao” and “Principles” by Ray Dalio. (NYT)

urn:contentItem:5RB1-KDF1-DXY4-X3WT-00000-00Peter Thiel Is a Bitcoin Believer: DealBook Briefing2018-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisSection Column 0Business/Financial DeskPg. Peter Thiel Is a Bitcoin Believer: DealBook Briefing

Good Tuesday and happy new year!

Bitcoin's value jumped as Peter Thiel's venture firm emerged as an investor in the currency.

Regulatory concerns sink Ant Financial's purchase of MoneyGram.

The Nasdaq Composite closed above 7,000 for the first time.

Breakingviews thinks 2018 will be a frothy, frustrating year.

The analyst Gene Munster thinks Amazon should make a big leap into brick-and-mortar retail.

Want this in your own email inbox? Here's the sign-up.

Peter Thiel is betting big on Bitcoin.

The value of the digital currency leapt about $1,000 this afternoon. Why? Turns out that the venture capitalist and his firm are believers.

From Rob Copeland of the WSJ:

Founders Fund, the venture-capital firm co-founded by Peter Thiel, has amassed hundreds of millions of dollars of the volatile cryptocurrency, people familiar with the matter said. The bet has been spread across several of the firm's most recent funds, the people said, including one that began investing in mid-2017 and made bitcoin one of its first investments.

As of this writing, Bitcoin is valued at about $14,655.

Why buy Bitcoin? Founders Fund is, after all, a venture firm rather than a hedge fund. But the firm apparently believes that start-up valuations currently are sky-high, while digital currencies will continue to climb in worth.

Has Founders Fund made money? The WSJ reports, citing its unnamed sources, that the firm bought about $15 million in Bitcoin and that its stake is now worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

-- Michael J. de la Merced

So much for Jack Ma's charm offensive.

So much for Jack Ma's charm offensive.

United States officials have effectively killed Ant Financial's $1.2 billion bid to buy MoneyGram.

Ant Financial, the electronic payments company controlled by Mr. Ma, became the latest Chinese firm to have its acquisition of an American company fall apart because it was unable to secure approval from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or Cfius.

The deal failed despite a charm offensive by Jack Ma, the Chinese internet. Shortly after President Trump won the 2016 election, Mr. Ma famously stood with the president-elect in Trump Tower in New York City and pledged that his e-commerce empire would help create one million American jobs.

The attempted purchase of MoneyGram was seen as a test of the Trump administration's political and regulatory approach to China, and the deal's failure could spell trouble for other Chinese companies considering major acquisitions.

The strong flow of Chinese money into the United States has prompted growing worries. Lawmakers from both parties have introduced legislation calling for greater scrutiny of Chinese investments in the United States. They are pushing for a significant expansion of Cfius, a multiagency panel that reviews foreign deals for potential threats to national security.

Of the deal, Richard Beales of Breakingviews writes:

''It would have been seen as something of a watershed for a successful upstart from the People's Republic to get its hands on a piece of Uncle Sam's payments infrastructure.

''For Trump and China critics in his administration, that may have been the wrong message, especially when a similar deal in the other direction would surely come up against Beijing's tight restrictions on foreign ownership in China's financial system. Rather than opening the door -- arguably the old American way of showing how things ought to be done -- CFIUS this time kept it closed. If it's a rebuke, it's one that's conveniently unlikely to provoke great resentment.''

MoneyGram's shares are down 6.8 percent after the close.

Tech's 2017 rally spilled over into the New Year

The Nasdaq Composite rose 1.5 percent Tuesday to close above 7,000 for the first time.

The gain was driven by Netflix, Facebook, Google-parent Alphabet and Apple, which jumped between 18 percent and 4.8 percent.

Tuesday's rally follows a 28 percent gain for the Nasdaq last year. That beat the 25 percent gain for the Dow Jones industrial average and the 19 percent rise for the Standard & Poor's 500 index.

So how stretched are valuations for the Nasdaq? As of Friday, the index was trading at 27.55 times the last 12 months of earnings, well above the S.&P. 500â€²s level of 18.27 times earnings, according to the WSJ's Ben Eisen. But the Nasdaq's current price-to-earnings ratio remains well below 72.2, which it hit in March 2000.

Extra Credit: Yes, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon.com drove the Nasdaq's run to 7,000. But Riot Blockchain saw the biggest percentage gain between the Nasdaq's first close above 6,000 in April to its close above 7,000 on Tuesday, writes the WSJ's Chelsey Dulaney. Shares of Riot ''surged more than 640 percent during that period, with the bulk of those gains coming after the company switched its focus to investing in blockchain technology October.''

Our thoughts exactly.

Shot: Senator Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, won't run for re-election, according to the NYT. That gives Mitt Romney -- former presidential candidate, former Massachusetts governor, former private equity mogul, current (and increasingly frequent) Trump critic -- a chance to run for the seat.

Chaser:

-- Michael J. de la Merced

Expect a ''frothy'' and ''frustrated'' 2018.

Money is cheap, the global economy is gaining momentum and markets are at records. ''Yet things look less reassuring close up,'' writes Quentin Webb of Breakingviews.

''The populist anger that enabled Trump and Brexit is still simmering, fueled by inequality, disruption, immigration and the echo chambers of social media. An unpredictable America is no longer committed to advancing a rules-based, liberal world order. China is growing increasingly assertive under President Xi Jinping, while Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is flexing his muscles around the Gulf. The risk of a conflagration on the Korean Peninsula is all too real. Business is grappling with self-inflicted scandals and activist attacks, and a backlash is building against Big Tech's overweening power.''

With that as the backdrop, here are a few of Breakingviews' predictions for 2018:

In investing

''For the first time in years, rich-world bond issuance will outstrip buying by the Fed and friends,'' and ''bond vigilantes will rise from the dead.''

''Passive funds will, despite their name, dethrone a chief executive.''

In tech

''In tech, investors can consider a tasty new dish: SLAW, for Spotify, Lyft, Airbnb and WeWork, four prospective candidates for public life.''

Apple's position as a privacy-sensitive hardware specialist will give it some shelter from mounting anger at Silicon Valley's power and lack of accountability.

-- Stephen Grocer

Dreaming of an Amazon-Target deal.

We're just two days into 2018, and we already have a huge M.&A. prediction, courtesy of the analyst Gene Munster.

From his note yesterday:

Getting the timing on this is difficult, but seeing the value of the combination is easy. Amazon believes the future of retail is a mix of mostly online and some offline. Target is the ideal offline partner for Amazon for two reasons, shared demographic and manageable but comprehensive store count.

It's a big, if logical, assumption given the ever-expanding empire that Amazon has been assembling -- one that has put more and more industry incumbents on their back heels.

Target shares were up nearly 4 percent as of this afternoon.

Could Amazon afford Target?

Short answer: Yes.

Long answer: Yes, but it'd be pretty expensive. Target's market capitalization as of Tuesday morning was nearly $37 billion. Amazon had about $24.3 billion in cash and short-term investments on its balance sheet as of Sept. 30, meaning that the company would have to borrow a hefty amount.

Assuming a 20 percent takeover premium, Target would be almost $40 billion.

Amazon could pay in stock as well as cash, but it hasn't struck a big deal using stock since its takeover of Zappos in 2009. And stock remains an expensive form of currency, though that hasn't stopped the likes of Disney from stock deals.

(Mr. Munster asserts that a deal is affordable because the cost of a Target acquisition is just 8 percent of Amazon's market cap. Obviously, I think it's a bit more complicated than that.)

The big caveat (other than price)

Obviously, it's antitrust. Mr. Munster notes that a combined Amazon-Target would only have about a 13 percent share of the overall American retail market, compared to Walmart's 23 percent.

But it's hard to determine at the moment what the Trump administration's yardstick for market concentration is:

AT&T and Time Warner say that their proposed deal is a vertical deal that falls within the bounds of acceptable deals. The Justice Department has sued to block that.

Disney and Fox have announced a deal that would inevitably lead to lots of layoffs. President Trump has praised that transaction as potentially ''great for jobs.''

''As for antitrust, the Trump administration won't do any favors for Jeff Bezos, but the market share numbers suggest the deal will be approved,'' Mr. Munster writes. That's a potentially big assumption.

-- Michael J. de la Merced

Are Amazon and Salesforce moving away from Oracle?

Kevin McLaughlin of The Information reports that the two companies ''are actively working to replace Oracle software running on critical business systems with open-source database software alternatives, and have made significant progress toward getting off Oracle entirely,'' citing people familiar with the matter.

''A mass exodus from the Oracle database isn't likely anytime soon. Yet losing Amazon and Salesforce as customers could pose major problems for Oracle, as it could provide a road map for other large companies that also are looking to cut costs by jettisoning Oracle database software in favor of open-source database alternatives.''

Oracle's shares are down nearly 2 percent. They had been trading about 1 percent higher before the report.

-- Stephen Grocer

Where are stocks heading in 2018?

The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 25 percent in 2017. Does that mean investors should turn bearish on stocks this year? The answer is no if history is any indicator, LPL Financial's Ryan Detrick points out.

Also, is the first day of trading predictive of the stock market's performance for the full year?

-- Stephen Grocer

Remembering 2017, and looking ahead to 2018.

If you couldn't recall last year's highlights over the recent holidays, Andrew can remind you with his annual year-end column (the humor of which is his and his alone). A sample:

The seating chart is, of course, always a bit complicated. We had to keep Jeffrey Bezos of Amazon from the dais to prevent Mr. Trump's Twitter war with him from interrupting the festivities. And we had heard that Mr. Bezos had a practical joke planned: He was going to tell Mr. Trump that he had chosen Mexico City as Amazon's second headquarters.

But it's a new year, and here are some important story lines we'll be keeping our eyes on:

Now that the tax fight is over, the White House is turning to trade. Will Gary Cohn and Steven Mnuchin be able to tame President Trump's hard-line tendencies?

Can Congress make progress on the many, many other issues it's facing?

SoftBank did its Uber deal. Will the ride-hailing giant make further strides toward going public this year? (Maybe not.) And what will Masa Son of SoftBank and his $100 billion Vision Fund get up to?

What other industries will Amazon disrupt this year? And how much bigger can Mr. Bezos's behemoth get?

North Korea is trying to drive a wedge between South Korea and the U.S. And it seems to be working. How will Mr. Trump -- and the global economy -- respond?

Stevie Cohen is finding takers for his new hedge fund. But how much presence will he retain in the industry?

In the world of M. & A. fights, who will AT&T or the Justice Department prevail? Broadcom or Qualcomm? And will Disney and Fox get their deal done?

Businesses are opening their wallets.

And the Trump administration's deregulatory push looks to be a reason for that -- even if skeptics question whether rolling back government rules stimulates corporate growth.

Corporate leaders always cite ''uncertainty'' as a reason to hold back on capital expenditures or transformative acquisitions. And fewer than half of the respondents in the National Association of Manufacturers' most recent survey said they faced an ''unfavorable business climate.''

Yet some see a bigger phenomenon at work. This is what Mark Zandi of Moody's Analytics told the NYT:

''The fundamental backdrop here is that this is a global synchronized expansion lifting everyone's spirits, from Tokyo to New York.''

The tax flyaround

Corporate America's great loophole scavenger hunt has begun. (NYT)

China has responded to the tax law by temporarily exempting foreign companies from taxes on their earnings in the country -- but there's a catch. (NYT)

Democrats in high-tax states are seeking ways to blunt some of the impact of the tax overhaul. (NYT)

The gig economy could get a boost. (NYT)

Betting on the dollar continuing to strengthen in 2018, thanks to the tax law. (WSJ)

The Murdoch family tensions behind the Disney deal.

It may have been a brief sales negotiation with Verizon that prompted Rupert Murdoch to consider selling pieces of 21st Century Fox. But the NYT reports that friction between the media mogul and his son James helped push the family toward the Disney transaction.

From the article by Brooks Barnes and Sydney Ember:

James Murdoch has privately grumbled about the control that his father still exerted at Fox and has chafed at some of the elements of Fox News's coverage.

Rupert Murdoch was wary of how Hollywood was being reshaped by digital giants like Netflix, Apple and Amazon, and unsure his empire could compete.

Lachlan Murdoch, who is more conservative than his brother, has become the heir apparent at what would remain of Fox, but was initially uneasy about a sell-off.

What they gain: Beyond easing family tensions among the trio, the deal could make the Murdochs some of Disney's biggest shareholders.

The mutual fund king bucking the low-fee wave.

Yes, Ron Baron has lowered fees on some of his smaller funds. But he's unapologetic about charging roughly 54 percent more than the industry average.

Here's what he told Landon Thomas Jr. of the NYT:

''Since inception, 98 percent of our funds have beaten their benchmark,'' he said in an interview. ''If you want the lowest fee, you should not invest with us.''

How he (and other mutual funds) do it: Chalk it up to a combination of looser oversight, the $10 trillion of investor money still dedicated to actively managed funds and a lack of investor awareness that high fees don't necessarily pay for performance.

Can this go on?

One fund investor's take in the NYT:

''I won't say performance warrants the fees they charge,'' said Barry Edelman, a Las Vegas retiree and a 20-year Baron shareholder. ''But I appreciate how they differentiate themselves from the competition.''

Tragedy strikes Bridgewater.

Bruce Steinberg, an executive at the hedge fund, and his family were among the 12 killed when a single-engine plane crashed in Costa Rica on Sunday.

Ray Dalio of Bridgewater posted this to Facebook yesterday:

Also of note: Richard Cousins, the C.E.O. of Compass Group, the world's biggest catering company, was one of six killed in a plane crash in Sydney on Sunday.

Hollywood organizes to fight sexual harassment.

What's notable is that Time's Up -- formed by more than 300 women and including a legal-defense fund -- isn't focused only on the entertainment industry. It plans to offer help to janitors, nurses, hotel staff and other blue-collar workers.

Here's what Shonda Rhimes, a backer of the initiative, told Cara Buckley of the NYT:

''If this group of women can't fight for a model for other women who don't have as much power and privilege, then who can?''

Who else is involved: The actresses America Ferrera, Eva Longoria and Reese Witherspoon; Donna Langley, the chairwoman of Universal Pictures; and roughly 295 other women in Hollywood.

What's different: The Time's Up Legal Defense Fund, which is backed by $13 million in donations and is overseen by Tina Tchen, a former chief of staff to Michelle Obama. It will help provide less-privileged women with lawyers to bring misconduct cases to court and protect them from blowback.

The misconduct flyaround

Take a peek behind the curtain at the monthly drug- and sex-fueled monthly parties attended by some of Silicon Valley's most powerful men, in an excerpt from ''Brotopia,'' the forthcoming book by the Bloomberg anchor Emily Chang. (Vanity Fair)

The former Fox News anchor Gretchen Carlson, who was a Miss America, will take over as chairwoman of the pageant as it works through its harassment scandal. (NYT)

Business schools in the United States are hastily reshaping their curriculums with case studies on sexual harassment. (NYT)

Political partisans are starting to exploit the #MeToo movement. (NYT)

The former C.E.O. of SoFi, Mike Cagney, has approached potential investors about backing a fintech start-up. (Recode)

The longtime leader of the New York City Ballet, Peter Martins, has retired after accusations of sexual harassment and verbal and physical abuse. He denies wrongdoing. (NYT)

Read this story. (Lloyd Blankfein said so.)

Last week, the NYT reported on how the Metropolitan Transportation Authority ends up with some of the highest construction costs in the world. Some facts:

The Second Avenue subway cost $2.5 billion. Expanding Grand Central Terminal is now expected to cost $12 billion.

Construction companies inflate their projected costs by up to 50 percent for M.T.A. work. Labor unions have arranged for up to four times the necessary staffing on some projects.

Consultants have persuaded officials to spend heavily on design and management.

Here's what Mr. Blankfein, Andrew's choice as 2017's best corporate tweeter, had to say:

(Mr. Blankfein has good reasons for pique over the tax law: Goldman Sachs is taking a $5 billion charge in its fourth-quarter earnings tied to the changes.)

The Speed Read

Caterpillar faces a potential tax bill of $2 billion from the I.R.S., which says it has underpaid on profits from parts sales through its Swiss unit. (WSJ)

The new Salesforce Tower in San Francisco is the tallest office building west of the Mississippi, and a symbol of tech's triumph in the city. (NYT)

Morgan Stanley is entering the robo-advice market, with an automated service that includes a choice of exchange-traded funds, mutual funds and seven themed portfolios. (FT)

Europe's new ''MiFID II'' investment rules -- on how research is paid for, how trades are documented and executed, and how brokers share information -- come into force tomorrow. (Bloomberg)

Playboy Enterprises is considering shutting the print magazine to concentrate on licensing deals and brand partnerships. (WSJ)

Retail cannabis shops in California opened their doors on Monday, inaugurating what proponents say will become the world's largest legal market for recreational marijuana. (NYT)

One of America's biggest rehab companies built an empire. But after a patient died, its enemies -- investors and rivals alike -- struck hard. (NYT)

Andrew picked his favorite business (and business-adjacent) books of 2017, including ''The Spider Network'' by David Enrich, ''Reset'' by Ellen Pao'' and ''Principles'' by Ray Dalio. (NYT)

We'd love your feedback as we experiment with the writing, format and design of this briefing. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com

urn:contentItem:5RTH-6CG1-DXY4-X1BM-00000-00Peter Thiel’s Money Talks, in Contentious Ways. But What Does He Say?2018-03-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYPeter Thiel’s Money Talks, in Contentious Ways. But What Does He Say?David Streitfeld

In a rare interview, the billionaire Facebook board member and Trump supporter shared his current takes on politics, Silicon Valley and more after “a crazier two years than I would have thought.”

Peter Thiel is Silicon Valley’s homegrown Cassandra. He warned for years that the big tech companies were arrogant and clueless and less good for mankind than they believed.

Comeuppance, the billionaire investor warned, was coming.

Trouble has now arrived. Unfortunately for Mr. Thiel, the storm is centered on Facebook, whose board he has been a member of practically since its founding. The social network, which billed itself as bringing democracy and enlightenment to the world, was used by the Russians to subvert democracy and sow confusion in the United States.

Even people paid to see the future didn’t see that one coming.

“The board’s role is to help think about some of the medium- and longer-term problems coming around the corner,” Mr. Thiel said. “We were far from perfect in doing that.”

Mr. Thiel, 50, is at the center of nearly every issue that roils Silicon Valley, ranging from the tech elite’s fascination with New Zealand hideaways (Mr. Thiel obtained New Zealand citizenship) to Bitcoin (he is a major investor) to the problems of herd thinking (he is moving from San Francisco to Los Angeles to escape it) to the evolving role of content on the internet (he has been exploring the creation of a media company that would outflank Breitbart and Fox for a younger audience).

Two subjects are currently overwhelming everything else: President Trump, whom Mr. Thiel aggressively backed for president, and Facebook, whose core mission is being called into question in the wake of the Russian revelations. In a typical Thiel move — he tends to run toward controversy even as his Silicon Valley peers try to make themselves inconspicuous — he agreed, in a rare interview, to talk about both.

“It’s been a crazier two years than I would have thought,” Mr. Thiel said in his new Midtown Manhattan apartment, which is so far up in the clouds that it literally looks down on Trump Tower.

Despite the proximity, the mutual enthusiasm between Mr. Thiel and Mr. Trump seems to have cooled. After Mr. Thiel spoke at the Republican National Convention in 2016, there were unsourced media reports that said Mr. Trump wanted to put him on the Supreme Court. But now even photo ops are rare.

The investor said he had last spoken to the president “a few months ago.”

“We don’t talk that often,” he said, but added, “I can get access anytime I want.”

The Trump whom Mr. Thiel touted at the Republican convention was a candidate who would “end the era of stupid wars and rebuild our country,” move us past “fake culture wars” and start projects the equivalent of the Apollo space program. That does not seem to be the president he got.

“There are all these ways that things have fallen short,” Mr. Thiel said. But he said he had no regrets about his endorsement. “It’s still better than Hillary Clinton or the Republican zombies,” he said, referring to the other candidates.

The White House did not respond to a request for comment.

Mr. Thiel is routinely labeled a libertarian. On a bookshelf in the apartment, as if in confirmation, is a hardback copy of Ayn Rand’s “Atlas Shrugged,” the bible of the movement. A gift, he said.

A lesser-known but possibly deeper influence was the French philosopher René Girard, who taught at Stanford University when Mr. Thiel was an undergraduate there. For 15 years, on and off, Mr. Thiel sat in on a study group about Mr. Girard’s ideas. Mr. Girard believed human beings were deeply mimetic, which is to say they copy one another.

“It’s very anti-Ayn Rand: There are no self-contained autonomous figures,” Mr. Thiel said. “Our desires are not our own. They get shaped powerfully by the society around us.”

It was this illumination that helped him see the potential of Facebook — where people could find out in intimate and addictive detail what their friends were up to — when it was barely a year old. He was the first outside investor, buying 10 percent of the company for $500,000.

He sold most of his holdings in 2012 as Facebook went public. A few months ago, with Facebook’s market capitalization at about $500 billion, he sold most of what he had left.

Last summer, there was a flap when a memo by a fellow board member, Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, appeared in The New York Times. In the memo, Mr. Hastings wrote to Mr. Thiel that he displayed “catastrophically bad judgment” in supporting Mr. Trump.

Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, did not ask him to step down from the board, and reports that he wants to leave the board are incorrect, Mr. Thiel said, noting that among other things he brings “ideological diversity.” He declined to say exactly how much or what kind of advice the Facebook board was offering Mr. Zuckerberg, but defended the company from criticism that it was slow to wake up to what the Russians did.

“Remember when Trump said the election was going to be rigged? People said that was crazy — ‘How dare you question the integrity of the electoral process?’ That was the view of most of the people working at Facebook, too,” he said. “They did not think things were so hackable. It was a mistake, but an understandable mistake.” Facebook declined to comment.

The anger now being turned on Facebook, Mr. Thiel argued, is less about Russia specifically and more about tech arrogance — its failure to do so much for so many. It is a sentiment that helped put Mr. Trump in the White House.

“The Trump campaign slogan, ‘Make America Great Again,’ was perhaps the single most offensive thing you could say to Silicon Valley,” he said. “Silicon Valley says the future is going to be better than the past. That is the propaganda, if you will.”

A friend of his in Silicon Valley had the idea of running for governor of California this year. Mr. Thiel’s advice was that he had better have a good answer to this question: Why is tech good for the average person in California? The answer, he cautioned, couldn’t be a banality, such as “it’s making us more connected,” and it couldn’t be utopian, such as “it’s going to cure all diseases.”

“He wasn’t able to come up with an answer, and I couldn’t come up with one, either,” Mr. Thiel said. He declined to identify the friend, but it is well known in tech circles that Sam Altman, the president of Y Combinator, the prominent start-up accelerator, was thinking about running. Mr. Altman confirmed it was him and said he had decided not to run “for many reasons.”

There is a big painting of a cresting wave in Mr. Thiel’s living room, and it might as well be a visual metaphor for what is going on in big tech now.

“Having some ambition that transcends just making money is a critical thing for a company,” he said. “But there is some point where it gets crazy and self-delusional.” He added that the companies “are probably in some trouble — maybe it’s a little, maybe it’s a lot.” The prospect of government regulation looms.

In 2015 and 2016, Mr. Thiel gave $300,000 to Josh Hawley, who was campaigning to become Missouri’s attorney general. Mr. Hawley won, and in November he opened an antitrust investigation of Google. A spokeswoman for Mr. Hawley, a Republican who is now challenging the state’s Democratic senator, Claire McCaskill, said there was “no connection” between Mr. Thiel’s donation and the investigation. Google declined to comment.

The news last month that Mr. Thiel is moving from San Francisco to Los Angeles reflects a shift that is as much mental as literal. Getting out of the tech bubble, he figures, will give him more clarity about his investments.

“Network effects are very positive things, but there’s a tipping point where they fall over into the madness of crowds,” he said.

Another of Mr. Thiel’s contentious ideas was destroying Gawker, the online publisher. He secretly financed the privacy lawsuit that Hulk Hogan, the former pro wrestler, filed against the media company, which Mr. Hogan won. That led to Gawker’s bankruptcy in 2016.

A news operation that specialized in deflating the arrogance of Silicon Valley should have been to Mr. Thiel’s liking. But he argues that his philosophy is consistent here.

“Gawker was trying to cut people down to size for not conforming,” he said. “The ability to speak and not have every word you say get distorted, to have wrong ideas and then be able to correct them — these notions were powerfully undercut by Gawker.”

Mr. Thiel is still pursuing the remnants of Gawker in court, which has prompted accusations that he wants to remove all of its content from the internet as a final victory.

He denied this. “Terry Bollea, a.k.a. Hulk Hogan, is still owed some money from the Gawker sale, and that is what I am trying to get,” he said. “I don’t want the archives. I don’t think it makes sense to destroy them. Preserve them, study them instead.”

urn:contentItem:529B-HCH1-JC11-90BS-00000-00PETROBANK ENERGY & RES LTD at CIBC World Markets Whistler Institutional Investor Conference - Final2011-01-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexis011911a3671696.796PETROBANK ENERGY & RES LTD at CIBC World Markets Whistler Institutional Investor Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* John Wright Petrobank Energy and Resources Ltd. - President and CEO

Conference Call Participants

* Andrew Potter CIBC World Markets - Analyst

Presentation

ANDREW POTTER, ANALYST, CIBC WORLD MARKETS: All right, we'll get started with the next session so up now is Petrobank. We have John Wright, Chairman, President and CEO presenting, and Peter Cheung on my right here who is the CFO of Petrobank.

For those not familiar with the Petrobank story, it is a very unique story in this space. What you've got here is basically a combination of two entities. You have got majority ownership of PetroBakken which the name is pretty self explanatory. It is more of a light oil resource play focus and you also buying Petrobank, get effectively a share of the heavy oil business unit which is focused on oil sands and heavy oil.

One of the things that obviously makes Petrobank very unique in the oil sands is that rather than pursuing the more traditional SAGD approach, the Company is attempting to commercialize its toe to heel air injection or THAI technology with applications in both oil sands and conventional heavy oil.

So we will do the presentation a little bit differently here. John will start walking through it but we will kind of pause throughout the presentation at various points to break for questions. So with that I guess I will turn it over to John to start going through the presentation.

JOHN WRIGHT, PRESIDENT AND CEO, PETROBANK ENERGY AND RESOURCES LTD.: Thanks, Andrew, and thanks all of you for joining us. We will see if this format works for the future because I don't think we have tried it before. Also with us today, Gregg Smith, who is the President and COO of PetroBakken is with us today as well as Bill Kanters, our VP New Ventures and Business Development. Gregg is presenting tomorrow and a third now -- a third member of the Petro family who has left home which is Petrominerales, Corey Ruttan will be here I think on Friday and presenting that part of the Petrobank family or the Petro story.

So I will just try and spin ahead here. A quick notice from our lawyers. I encourage you to read that at your leisure.

So the Petrobank story is getting a little simpler. The Company itself is effectively three separate assets. So we have our majority ownership of PetroBakken, which used to be our 100% own Canadian business unit and through a transaction we initiated in about October of 2009, we spun off PetroBakken through essentially a takeover of TriStar. And since that time, PetroBakken has been operating in the Canadian conventional light oil space and is the premier operator of horizontal drilling with multi-stage fracturing. And again, I invite you to visit Gregg's presentation tomorrow to learn more about that.

Petrobank also owns our heavy oil operating subsidiary, Whitesands, which has a pretty significant asset base in both bitumen and heavy oil in Alberta and Saskatchewan and I will get into that in a little bit more detail here. And then finally, a little unique for an oil and gas company but we own a technology company called Archon, and Archon actually is an active research and development arm of the company. We own now eight patents or pending patents on technologies related to heavy oil recovery. I'll show you a little bit later on in this presentation if we get to it, those patents have been now registered in 10 different countries on a global basis and they are waiting for final registration and recognition in a further 34 countries. So there is a big tech company part of Petrobank that sort of hides underneath the corporate umbrella.

So when you buy a share of Petrobank today, you get a little bit more than one share of PetroBakken, you get 100% ownership in those two business units which includes a very substantial reserve and resource position in the bitumen world where we have got about 669 million barrels of 2p and best estimate contingent resource available in the McMurray region.

And then a further access to about a further 80 million barrels of capability in the more conventional world in Seal and Kerrobert where we are looking at heavy oil not unlike the heavy well that you would find globally throughout most of the other basins of the world.

The Company itself has a really strong balance sheet, ended last quarter the third quarter with a little bit of net cash in hand. We actually accumulate well over CAD100 million a year in dividends from our stake in PetroBakken and as well, we have access to about a CAD200 million line of credit which again was not drawn at the end of the last reporting period.

I am going to skip by some of this stuff just so we can get into the meat of the matter but I mentioned we have got a pretty significant reserve and resource base. And at the end of last year as part of our ongoing and I think we have been pretty public about this, our ongoing plan to unlock value for shareholders, we spun off our majority interest in another one of the subsidiaries we created which is Petrominerales and provide some graphical data here. Obviously these valuations will fluctuate from day to day based on what the market says.

But I think what we are trying to say is there has been a lot of value creation by the Petrobank team. We have been able to create specific vehicles that are able to unlock some of those values in very unique circumstances and most recently, with the spinoff of Petrominerales and the continued higher liquidity in the market for Petrominerales and Petrobank that has evolved, I think we have continued to create some pretty good growth in the Company overall basin.

If you add all the pieces together I think a share of Petrobank recombined today would be worth about CAD47 or so round numbers just to put us in perspective.

I am not going to get into a bunch of detail on PetroBakken other than to tell you this is a company that is built for long-term accretive growth. We have got about 2000 drilling locations on the two biggest resource plays for light oil in Canada which is the Bakken and the Cardium in Alberta. And the team in place at PetroBakken has drilled, completed and brought on stream more horizontal wells with multistage frac technology than anyone else in this country. They have got a ton of experience and they are applying it with a very aggressive program this year which should so show some very, very impressive growth numbers through the end of the year and I think they are really starting to spin out some great results on our Cardium opportunity. And I will leave it at that.

That is kind of a good place to break if there's any questions about the macro corporate structure if you have any and if not, I can go on.

Questions and Answers

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: I have a question about Archon.

JOHN WRIGHT: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: I guess a common criticism of the oil sands (inaudible) for an industry that is really dependent on technology (inaudible)

JOHN WRIGHT: Do we need to repeat the questions?

ANDREW POTTER: Yes, that actually helps.

JOHN WRIGHT: Okay, so the question is whether Archon is unique or whether the oil industry is sort of going that way. I think there was a recent article in the Globe and Mail that kind of captured it lately that said that more and more people in our industry are starting to recognize there is value not just in oil and gas resource but in the technologies that we are developing. And I don't think in any way that Archon is unique. I think we have been around for a long time and I think we have been pretty forward about filing patents and getting global recognition for some of the things we have done.

But an awful lot of the major innovations that have taken place in the global oil industry have originated in Canada and certainly what you are seeing with multistage fracking for example, that has been a huge push-out using the Packers Plus system for example which is a made in Canada success story. It is now in just about every country on earth showing some great results. And SAGD was another huge innovation that came out of the Canadian mind think.

And I think we have to remember that Alberta well, the Western Canadian sedimentary basin is very mature and really offers very little conventional opportunity now. So anything that we can do to create value in that basin is probably going to be unique and will be copied in other parts of the world. And it goes forward and no one will question that Exxon and Shell and BP have huge research organizations but if you drive by the University of Calgary, you will also see they have huge research centers that are working on that right now and Archon is just another one of them focused on -- Archon by the way is the god of fire. So it is focused on in situ combustion and thermal recovery methods for heavy oil.

ANDREW POTTER: Just on that topic, I mean what is the longer-term game plan for the different entities? Do you ultimately see spinning off the heavy oil business unit and Archon into separate entities down the road?

JOHN WRIGHT: Yes, thanks, Andrew. We have been pretty forthright about saying that we are all together in Petrobank as shareholders but we think we can unlock a lot a value by holding the different assets through different pieces of paper. So Petrominerales being spun off was a natural progression. It will be natural for us to ultimately unlock further value in PetroBakken by putting that in the hands of all the shareholders.

I think we can do the same thing with the heavy oil assets in Archon. Archon, the long-term business model there is actually to create a revenue generating capability through licensing and royalty opportunities that we have been working on for the technologies and that has no -- there is no peer for that in the oil and gas world. And I am not suggesting for a minute it is Microsoft or Apple, but it will trade like a high-tech company because it won't have reserves or capital requirements to invest in wells and so forth. It will essentially be marketing that technology and our long-term plan is to create that as a profit center and again put it in the hands of the shareholders.

Okay, I will just jump on. So jumping into what the heavy oil assets look like in Petrobank, we are focused in three specific areas. One is the conventional being the wrong word but the kind of the common thought around heavy oil and bitumen is the Fort McMurray and Athabasca oil sands and we have got a pretty huge resource base there. Everyone talks about how many billions of barrels they have. We have got about 1.6 billion barrels of bitumen in place on our asset there of which a little less than 700 million would be recoverable as estimated by our independent auditors using SAGD technology.

So it is a great resource base in a very active area that I think a lot of people are familiar with. We also have a big heavy oil resource base in the Dawson region which is in the Seal or Peace River part of Alberta and that is more conventional oil. This is oil that will actually flow cold and probably looks a lot more like the oil you will see in Colombia and Peru and the Middle East and China and Russia and Madagascar and places like that where it isn't bitumen but it is still very hard to get out of the ground.

And then sort of a huge resource in the Province of Saskatchewan, the massive heavy oil reserves that have been developed and brought on stream under conventional production. It's about 20 billion barrels of heavy oil in place in Saskatchewan and less than 5% of that is recoverable under conventional recovery methods. So there is a huge proven known discovered delineated resource base just sitting there in one of the most hospitable places to do business in Canada and we have got a chunk of it in a region called Kerrobert and we are always on the lookout for other opportunities that look like that.

We put on here just so to put things in perspective when you talk about billions, the Southeast Saskatchewan Bakken light oil play, resource play there is about a five billion barrel accumulation so it is almost dwarfed by all these big heavy oil accumulations that are out there. And the asset bases have to be converted into prospective developments so we have identified between 27,000 and 127,000 barrels a day of projects just on the three operating areas that we have put in place to date. And the first one is going to be at Kerrobert where we are actually building up a 7000 barrel a day project which I and going to get into in a little bit of time here.

When we talk about the THAI technology and I have got a little picture that describes it but maybe just say it in words, we kind of look at it as being able to get significantly more oil out of the ground at a significantly lower capital cost and a significantly lower operating cost, higher net back. And the idea there is because we are using fire, because we are using combustion in the ground as our heat source, we are able to actually displace and recover a much higher quantity of the oil in place than we would be if we were using steam which is a fairly passive way to deliver heat into the reservoir.

On the capital investment side, it is not a function of Petrobank having some secret way of spending less money. We literally invest in less equipment to put in place a THAI project. And by that I mean if you've visited any of our operating sites there, they are easily the least impressive field operations you are ever going to see because we don't have any massive boilers or big steam generators or water treating facilities or cooling towers or anything like that. We have an air compressor and an oil battery and it is pretty boring. But it is also pretty cheap. It can be built very quickly and so the capital investment can be very low and I am going to show you in our Kerrobert economics shockingly low for the heavy oil business in what we think is the best opportunity on our books to date.

And then on the net back side, because we are producing oil without steam and without producing three or four barrels of water for every barrel of oil we produce or anything like that, we don't have big water treating facilities. We don't have to recirculate our produced water or anything like that. We don't consume natural gas to create steam on the surface. So we have a very low operating cost base and we can show you some operating costs we are predicting will be sub CAD10 a barrel to run a full commercial THAI operation.

There is also on an ancillary basis but very positive basis some huge environmental positives about this technology. We can reduce our greenhouse gas emissions per barrel. We can significantly reduce the surface footprint because we use less facilities. We have produced an upgraded barrel of oil which means we have less refining, less upgrading that has to happen to our barrel.

And finally, we don't consume water so we take ourselves out of the whole water equation which has become a big part of the discussion around heavy oil recovery.

So this is what THAI looks like sort of in a slice of lasagna underground here. And you can kind of see the horizontal wells are the drainage wells at the bottom of the reservoir. At the toe of every horizontal well we drill a vertical air injection well. We inject air into that well. The air hits the reservoir. It combusts the oil. The oil starts to burn.

The best analogy we have is think about the charcoal briquettes on your barbecue. The more you blow on them the redder they get, the hotter they glow and they generate a bunch of heat. That heat is actually sufficient to crack the oil in situ so we drop out a significant portion of the heavy ends of the barrel in the form of coke in the reservoir so think of it as carbon dust in the reservoir. So a solid. That becomes the fuel for the fire. So we are actually burning coke in the reservoir to generate this heat.

The liberated oil is now very mobile. It flows like water. We create a drain point at the base of the reservoir which is like the drain in your bathtub so by gravity, all the flow goes down to the base of the reservoir and then up to the surface where we process it. And this is what the Kerrobert facility looks like and in fact is being drilled up at this moment and we will be on production next quarter.

I don't know, maybe that is a good place to stop for questions too if there are any. Any questions about the technology itself?

ANDREW POTTER: Any questions from the floor?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (Inaudible question - microphone inaccessible).

JOHN WRIGHT: So the question is how universally applicable THAI is in the heavy oil world. So we have a pretty simple mantra. THAI will work in almost all sandstone reservoirs provided that there is enough permeability to actually get a high flux rate of air into the ground. So in engineering terms, we are looking at darcy plus rock so very high permeability rock.

To put that in perspective, the McMurray Sands in the Athabasca region and Fort McMurray region are 10 plus darcy sands. These Kerrobert sands are 2 to 3 darcy sands. Most shallow unconsolidated well sorted sand can have permeability in the 1 to 10 darcy range.

I will put that in perspective. The Bakken has a permeability of less than 1 millidarcy. So it is 1000 times less permeable than these types of reservoirs.

It probably doesn't lend itself well to carbonates. Carbonates are very buggy and not very consistent. And one of the issues that you have when you generate, you can probably effectively do it, but when you generate a high amount of heat in a carbonate reservoir, you also generate a lot of carbon dioxide. And I think until we have sort of got our heads around carbon capture and things like that, that is probably not where we want to go with it right now.

But the huge majority of heavy oil on earth is in sandstone reservoirs with high permeability so this has great applicability on a global basis.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: (Inaudible question - microphone inaccessible).

JOHN WRIGHT: So the question is do I want to make a prediction for next quarter? So we have kind of built our careers at Petrobank over the last 11 years by not making quarter-over-quarter projections and I think it is enough that we are trying a fireside chat format here. I am not going to change everything else about us.

But I will say to we are very comfortable with the results we have had from Kerrobert. The new well design that we have put in place there you know things to continue to evolve for us. I mean I want you to know this isn't a static technology. We are tweaking it on a regular basis but we are very excited about getting good commercial production out of Kerrobert and we expect oil out of the ground in the second quarter. And we have said and I think we are comfortable saying this within a year we hope to be ramped up to the 7200 barrel a day area. So sometime in the second quarter of 2012, we would hope to be up at full commercial rates here.

By the way, the project is commercial at rates much less than that but it is designed to go up to 600 barrels a day per well is the design right now.

I talked a little bit about reserves. This can get pretty technical and I am just going to skip this but I am happy to come back if someone has a question. The bottom line is compared to a SAGD reservoir, we think if we apply THAI to it we should be able to double the effective reserves. So for the same reservoir, the same project, different technology, twice the reserve recovery.

So this is what Kerrobert looks like in plan view and when I talk about Saskatchewan, you can kind of see we have stripped all the Viking oil wells off this map or it would just look like a big black mass because it is very heavily drilled in this region. But you can see all the heavy oil development that has happened here over the last 50 years.

A mile away from our project, our THAI project, there is a working SAGD project. I think last time we looked it was doing about 1300 barrels a day. So there is good baseline production here. There has been coal production for decades. What we are putting in place is the development in the kind of the heart of our asset base in Kerrobert which you will see us drilling it up with a total of 12 wells. And we've got some economics here and I will skip ahead a page here after this but 12 wells targeting 7200 barrels a day.

But I think the most exciting thing for us is this is a 7200 barrel a day project that effectively started drilling in January and will be on production in April. So it is not the timeline you have heard out for the big mine developments or even some of the bigger SAGD developments. This is the number of wells that Gregg Smith and his team at PetroBakken will drill in two weeks of work but will take a couple of months to get them all drilled in our method. But they will be onstream right away.

So air starts going into the ground sometime around the end of the first quarter. Oil is being produced in the second quarter so we will have some by heavy oil and bitumen standards, we will have some lightning fast results on this and get them to you.

There is some great numbers that go around here. I want to emphasize Kerrobert is probably one of the best economic opportunities on our books today. That is why we are putting so much effort into it. It is a very easy operating area. We are in the middle of a very flat farmland. All the surface is privately owned. We have great relationships with all the local farmers, local landowners. There is paved roads, there is Motel 6s, there is Tim Horton's and 7-11s. We don't have to run a camp operation. We have never seen a helicopter. This is as good as it gets and as easy as it gets.

And the only thing I want to emphasize about Kerrobert is there is probably 50 look-alikes to Kerrobert in Saskatchewan within a 50-mile radius of where we are operating because that is what Saskatchewan is like.

There is some great numbers that we are showing here as far as there is a little bit of a rate of return matrix at the bottom there compares oil prices to flow rates. But I think the big takeaway here is we are targeting 600 barrels a day per well for these projects. They are more than economic at 150 barrels a day which is a typical Bakken oil well for example.

And the capital investment here I mean I don't think we will ever get lower than this sort of CAD12,000 a flowing barrel rate but I mean that is literally a quarter of what a typical SAGD is costing today. And remembering that we are also generating an upgraded oil here. And by that, I can kind of show you the oil on the left is raw Kerrobert crude. It is about a 10 API gravity which means it is exactly the same density as water. It is very heavy crude. It is very viscous, thousands of centipoise of viscosity in its native state.

And what we have been producing because we are actually coking the oil in situ is oil that has been as upgraded as being 20 or 21 degrees API. And you can see over the last little period there that there has been a trend downward and a flattening and a kind of a -- we have got things moderated in the reservoir. It doesn't mean that that is where we are going to be operating things on the long-term but what we have been doing out of Kerrobert with a different corporate goal in mind is we have been trying to level load the facility, make everything run on a steady-state basis, not necessarily at full capacity but just to make sure our reserve auditors and ourselves are on the same perspective so that we can ultimately get recognized proved reserves for the whole Kerrobert project, and by analogy for Whitesands and for Dawson. So that has been a big part of our focus there.

But even at that lower level of air injection and lower pump rates, we are still seeing upgrades into the 15 degree API range which is a huge success for us.

Just jumping back into Alberta at our May River project, this is in big oil territory so you can see the Petrobank lands in red there. To the East, we have some familiar names, Devon Jackfish Lake, Cenovus, Christina Lake. To the west is the big Statoil land block. This gray block immediately to the west of us which is the Thai National Oil Company recently made a CAD2 billion investment. This is kind of the heart of heavy oil country for Alberta.

And what we have here right now is a three-well pilot project. We make the joke now that everything you see at our Conklin pilot will never be duplicated in any of our commercial projects. It has been our learning center. It has been a place where we tried a bunch of new technology. We have got plans to test some new ideas there but it essentially is a museum to our first attempts at applying the technology.

What we will be rolling out in May River is the first 10,000 barrels a day of our ultimate 100,000 barrels a day project. This project is currently waiting on regulatory approval from the government of Alberta but it is designed, we pre-purchased some of the equipment and when the time comes we have obviously missed another drilling window here this winter. But when the time comes, we will be able to get after this and get up to a full scale development.

This will be more expensive than Kerrobert. It will be -- it will take longer than Kerrobert because it is a tougher operating environment. But I think at the end of the day it will be a very, very big resource opportunity for us.

The last place you are going to see us drilling this year is at Dawson which is a look-alike to Kerrobert and we are literally going to take our old Kerrobert plant, drill up Dawson in the second and third quarter and put that Kerrobert plant to work for us there and have some oil out of here by Q3 or Q4 this year.

And I am kind of winding up to the end here. If you think Alberta and Saskatchewan have a lock on all the heavy oil on earth you are sadly mistaken. There is about 9 trillion barrels of heavy oil on a global basis. We show some of the main basins here where heavy oil has been accumulated. Alberta and Saskatchewan are leading the way in devising new ways to recover this but the wave of the future will be heavy oil from all of these basins on a global basis.

The red stars are of the countries where we already have THAI patented and licensed or unavailable for licensing in country. There is a further 34 countries where we are going through the process to get that in place and obviously we think there is some big licensing opportunities, joint venture opportunities on a global basis to go after that.

ANDREW POTTER: We have got about one minute so we will have one quick question from the floor.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Some of the biggest challenges to getting these license agreements is that they want to see more success before they commit or is it just a matter of negotiating (inaudible)

JOHN WRIGHT: The question was the biggest challenges to the licensing agreement. So our issue is outside of North America, Colombia, Peru, that is about it, outside of those regions, almost all the heavy oil on earth is controlled by governments, by state oil companies or energy ministers. So our negotiation goes from being commercial to being political very quickly.

We announced in December that we had actually withdrawn a license deal that we put in place with a national oil company, primarily because we got stuck in the political machinations there. So I think it is a combination of finding the right political mix and fitting the political mindset of some governments that aren't necessarily pro-new technology or pro-sharing the wealth or pro-foreign investment and finding a way to make a difference for both of us so that it is a win-win and it is a long tough process.

It is much easier to do deals in North America and Latin America where the business climate sort of fits our way of thinking. But I think long-term Archon is developing that capability to do these deals with these big state entities and we do have other negotiations in place right now that are proceeding.

But at the end of the day, there is always a political element to some of those that we obviously can't control and ultimately have to be very careful on behalf of our shareholders for.

ANDREW POTTER: I guess with that we will wrap it up. We will pause for a few minutes as we move over to the services panel but thanks John and Peter for that presentation.
