By Ghaith Madadha AMMAN - Launched as a modern-day successor to Fiat's iconic, original and ultra-small 500 people's car, the new 500 capitalised on it's predecessor's chic and iconography, and sought to emulate the BMW-era Mini's success story as a small but desirable and fashionable city car. Larger and heavier than its forbearer due to modern safety regulations and equipment levels, the new 500 has been a hit with buyers and reviewers since 2007 and was offered with a line-up of four-cylinder petrol and turbo-diesel engines, which are now joined by a two-cylinder engine emulating the original 500, and its use of bi-cylinder power. Developed by Fiat for a contemporary setting and a greener and more efficient near future of largely congested and urbanised driving with high fuel prices, the 0.9 TwinAir engine will come in several iterations of power output and will be fitted more widely across Fiat's automobile range, but to start with has found its logical and spiritual home with the retro-chic 500. However, unlike the 1957-75 500 with it's ancient air-cooled 0.5- and 0.6-litre engines producing between 13BHP to 23BHP, Fiat's modern two-cylinder is a high tech marvel that offers a uniquely charismatic petrol combustion engine solution for green and efficient motoring.

Big tech, small package Lighter, cheaper, less complex and more viscerally fun than hybrid, electric or even turbo-diesel green alternatives, the 0.9 TwinAir is a breath of tightly packaged fresh air with a peaky and buzzy persona. Developed using Fiat's latest automotive technology, the 0.9 TwinAir's efficient engineering solutions include direct fuel injection and electro-hydraulic valves, which cut fuel consumption by an estimated 10 per cent and raise power and torque by 10 per cent and 15 per cent respectively. The 0.9 TwinAir's reduced cylinder count also reduces friction for better efficiency and responsiveness, which surprisingly even translated into minimal lag before its turbo spools up to deliver its punchiest performance. Though more costly to produce than larger more conventional 1.2- and 1.4-litre naturally-aspirated four-cylinder engines offered on the 500, the 0.9 TwinAir's substantial price premium makes most sense in a heavily urbanised setting where its even greater fuel savings recoup the initial investment, while its petrol engine technology does not require costlier or more specialised maintenance like hybrid and electric vehicles. In the UK, the 500 0.9 TwinAir is considered so clean that it is exempt from inner city congestion charges, while 0.9 TwinAir engine version models could be expected to become less expensive in future when it becomes more widely used in other Fiats, probably stating with the Panda. Twin virtues Set to be produced in 64bhp and 104bhp versions as well, the current 0.9 TwinAir engine develops 84bhp at 5500rpm and 107lb/ft torque at 1900rpm, which equates to a highly prodigious 96bhp per litre. Compared with the 500's base four-cylinder engines, the 0.9 TwinAir outpowers the 1.2 by 16bhp and falls short of the 1.4 by 15bhp, but compensates with a reduced weight, 32lb/ft and 10lb/ft more torque respectively and a lighter weight. The 0.9 TwinAir also delivers its maximum torque much earlier, and offers a broad and rich torque band to help make the 500 responsive and flexible in terms of driving character. With impressive output figures, the Fiat 500 0.9 TwinAir manual gearbox with dash to 100km/h in 11-seconds and on to 173km/h, which is just short of the 1.4's 10.5-seconds and 182km/h, but noticeably better than the 1.2's 12.9-seconds and 160km/h. In terms of fuel economy and emissions the 0.9 MultiAir's advantage is much more pronounced, with 4.9-litre urban, 3.7l extra urban and 4.1l combined consumption per 100km/h and just 95g/km combined CO2 emissions. By comparison, the manual gearbox 1.2 returns 5.1l/100km combined consumption and produces 119g/km CO2, and the manual 1.4 scores 6.3l/100km combined and 149g/km emissions combined. Responsive and refined With some 25 per cent more torque at 1900rpm than the 1.4-litre 500, the 0.9 TwinAir feels surprisingly confident and modestly swift for its diminutive displacement, and while there is a rich torque band, one enjoys and feels encouraged to use its slick five-speed manual gearbox often and rev the engine right up to 6000rpm often to get the best performance. With good on-the-move and mid-range responsiveness, the 0.9 outclasses its larger stablemates, while a balancer shaft is so effectively used to smooth out the two-cylinder's natural on/off power strokes, one is hard-pressed to notice anything but a slight charismatic gruffness at idle or full load to suggest it's two-cylinder configuration. Featuring recent suspension and steering set-up changes, the Fiat 500 has also become a more comfortable and better planted car and drives more smoothly over imperfect roads, and offers better cabin refinement. A small, light and agile car, the 500 has never been more fun to throw around tight and zig-zagging corners, with a better weighted steering and more feedback complementing the 0.9 engine's lighter front-end weight. Eager to turn-in and tight through a swift corner, the 500 can also be easily controlled when pushed too hard and fast into oversteer, simply by easing off and modulating throttle input. Charismatic city car At it's best zipping through traffic and city streets, the 500 0.9 is manoeuvrable and responsive, and with city mode switched on, its steering becomes lighter but more communicative, while a stop start system deactivates the engine when one comes to a complete stop in neutral and re-fires the twin cylinder when the clutch is depressed, so as to further cut fuel costs. Charismatic, classy and chic, the 500 0.9's cute bubbly and retro-inspired lines and big footprint with a wide track and short overhang give it a feisty, road-hugging and athletic yet urbanised unisex appeal, very much like the hugely popular Mini. Disarmingly charismatic, the Fiat 500's interior is dominated by circular themes and has a chic and quality retro-modern ambiance. Though looking back through rose-tinted glasses, the 500's interior has all the modern trappings of convenience one would need of a contemporary compact city car, as well as comfortable and well-adjustable seats to accommodate even taller drivers. With good in class material quality, the 500's interior is airy, detailed, fun and sporty, with sports steering wheel, an upright driving position, and high-set seats and a sporty gear-lever positioned high in the centre console. With a commanding position, enhanced by its small dimensions and short sloped bonnet, the 500 has good visibility. Front space is good, while rear seats and boot space is decent for a car this size.   Technical specifications Engine: 0.9-litre, turbocharged, transverse 2-cylinders Bore x stroke: 80.5 x 86mm Compression ratio: 10:1 Valve-train: 8-valve, electro-hydraulic valves, direct injection, DOHC Gearbox: 5-speed manual, front-wheel-drive Top gear ratio: 0.77:1 Power, PS (BHP) [kW]: 85 (84) [63] @ 5500rpm Specific power: 96bhp/litre Torque, lb/ft (Nm): 107 (145) @ 1900rpm Specific torque: 165.7Nm/litre Power-to-weight: 83.6bhp/tonne 0-100 km/h: 11-seconds Top speed: 173km/h CO2 emissions: 95g/km Fuel consumption, urban/extra-urban/combined: 4.9/3.7/4.1 litres/100km Fuel capacity: 35 litres Height: 1488mm Width: 1627mm Length: 3546mm Wheelbase: 2300mm Tread, front/rear: 1413/1407mm Weight: 1005kg Tyres: 175/55R14 Steering: rack and pinion, power-assisted Suspension, front: Independent, Macpherson strut, lower wishbone, anti-roll bar Suspension, rear: Independent, torsion bar Brakes, front/rear: ventilated disc 240mm/drum 180mm

urn:contentItem:60FT-M211-DXKX-04HN-00000-00Pew: 72% of Americans Say Social Media Companies Have Too Much Political Clout They're Right2020-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:30ZLexisNexisPew: 72% of Americans Say Social Media Companies Have Too Much Political Clout They're Right

Jul 27, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/Delivered by Newstex) Even in an election year as divided and chaotic as 2020, millions of Americans can seem to agree that Big Tech has too much political clout.An overwhelming majority of Americans are skeptical over Big Tech's unchecked power, a Pew Research Center (Pew) study has found. In addition, about half of Americans surveyed also believe the government should do more to regulate them. 'Overall, 72% of U.S. adults say social media companies have too much power and influence in politics today, according to the June 16-22 survey Pew's FactTank outlet observed[1] July 22.Even during a polarized election year, Americans across the political spectrum seem to agree that Big Tech needs to be brought to heel, as 'Majorities of both Republicans and Democrats believe social media companies wield too much power.' That said, Republicans are more likely to hold this view as 'Roughly eight-in-ten Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (82%) think these companies have too much power and influence in politics, compared with 63% of Democrats and Democratic leaners.'Even liberal Democrats are 'somewhat more likely than moderate or conservative Democrats to agree with this assessment (68% vs.

60%).' In short, party hardliners of both the left and right share the common cause of calling for Big Tech companies' power to be held in check. The Pew survey appears to show that this is continuation of previously observed trends[2]. A previous survey demonstrated that 'Republicans were more likely than Democrats to believe social media sites censor political viewpoints and that tech companies generally support liberal views over conservative ones.' Yet even so, both sides largely agree that Big Tech is a problem that needs to be dealt with.Within the GOP, even while disagreeing on other matters, voters are largely unified about this issue. The most recent study found that 'nine-in-ten conservative Republicans (89%) think these companies have too much power,' while a slightly smaller majority (74%) 'of moderate or liberal Republicans' largely agree. As a result, one salient development since 2018 that the article makes clear is that 'Conservative Republicans are the only ideological group who have become more likely to favor increased regulation.'This summer has been a crucible of Big Tech controversies, only accelerating the already present tensions of an election year.In late May, Twitter fact-checked President Donald Trump[3] for suggesting that mail-in ballots could lead to voter fraud, a concern even The New York Times has acknowledged to be valid[4]. While undermining the president of the United States, Twitter has racked up an impressive record of liberal bias[5], including allowing blatant Chinese propaganda[6] to be spread among Americans.Facebook censored Trump with a new policy[7] that undermined his posts critiquing the hazards of mail-in voting by placing an interstitial showing users how and where to start the process themselves.Google gave a measly mea culpa[8] earlier this month after several conservative websites were delisted from its general search and appeared to have been blacklisted. Google critic Dr. Robert Epstein[9] wrote that Google gave at least 2.6 million votes to Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton in 2016 and that it could sway 'upward of 15 million votes' in the Democrats' favor in 2020. Google Responsible Innovation Head Jen Gennai was caught in 2018 suggesting that 'breaking up Google' would not 'prevent the next Trump situation.'[10] She also mused how changes in Google's secret algorithms could have prevented his election from happening in the first place.Apple snuck COVID-19 contract tracing technology[11] into one of its phone updates back in May. The technology, in theory, would notify users when they enter the presence of a person with the coronavirus. This despite surveys that have shown[12] that three in five Americans are either unable or entirely unwilling to use the technology.Amazon brushed off concerns about letting an anti-Christian organization like SPLC decide which groups may receive funds, blocking pro-life and pro-family organizations like Alliance Defending Freedom and the Family Research Council from receiving funds. MRC President L. Brent Bozell announced that[13] the Media Research Center would no longer accept money from the AmazonSmile program. He declared that 'Any money from Amazon is tainted, hate-filled money that we want nothing to do with.'Conservatives are under attack. This Wednesday, the CEO's of major Big Tech companies, including Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, Apple CEO Tim Cook, Google CEO Sundar Pichai and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will testify before the House Judiciary Antitrust, Commercial, and Administrative Law Subcommittee[14]. Give the subcommittee a call at 202-225-3951 and demand that Big Tech be held to account. If you have been censored, contact us at the Media Research Center contact form[15], and help us hold Big Tech accountable.
